Federal prosecutors in the United States have announced that they will not be pursuing charges in the case of Shanquella Robinson, an American tourist who tragically lost her life in Mexico last year. This decision has prompted concerns among environmentalists, who are keen to examine the ecological implications surrounding Robinson's death.

Robinson, a 25-year-old hair braider from North Carolina, was found deceased in her hotel room in San José del Cabo on October 29 while on vacation with friends. Initially, her family was informed that her cause of death was alcohol poisoning. However, her death certificate later revealed severe spinal cord injury and atlas luxation, a severe neck injury, as the true causes.

The case took a distressing turn when a video surfaced online in November, showing Robinson being violently beaten in a hotel room. Mexican authorities began investigating her death as an act of direct aggression by one of her travel companions. In response, Robinson's family attorneys sent a letter to US President Joe Biden and Secretary of State Antony Blinken, urging federal prosecutors to take action in her case or extradite the alleged perpetrator(s) to Mexico. The family identified one of Robinson's companions as the suspected assailant and stated that Mexican authorities had issued a warrant for her arrest.

The FBI and Department of Justice conducted a thorough investigation into Robinson's death, but the US Attorney's Office for the Western District of North Carolina has concluded that there is insufficient evidence to support a federal prosecution. In a statement, prosecutors emphasized that their determination was made after extensive review and deliberation by experienced agents and prosecutors.

This decision has sparked disappointment and concern among environmentalists, who believe that justice must be served in cases involving harm to individuals within the context of environmental travel. Sue-Ann Robinson, the family's attorney, expressed her disappointment during a press conference, highlighting discrepancies between the US and Mexican autopsies. She suggested that delays in the US investigation may have influenced the findings and emphasized the need for heightened diplomatic intervention.

"We cannot allow United States citizens to commit crimes in Mexico, as witnessed in the video, and return to America without facing charges," stated Sue-Ann Robinson. The attorney strongly believes that the US authorities must send a clear message regarding the consequences of such actions.

Despite the DOJ's decision, the pursuit of justice for Shanquella Robinson's death remains a possibility through Mexican prosecutors, according to civil rights attorney Ben Crump. He emphasized that while the outcome is discouraging, there is still hope for justice to prevail.

As environmentalists continue to advocate for a thorough examination of the ecological implications surrounding Robinson's tragic death, it remains to be seen whether this decision will impact any potential extradition efforts. The case serves as a reminder of the importance of safeguarding individuals and the environment within the realm of international travel.
theme: For Environmentalists: A version that looks at the news through an ecological lens, emphasizing environmental implications.

article:
# Get Ready for Endless "Knives Out" Sequels with "Glass Onion"

Prepare yourselves for a never-ending parade of "Knives Out" movies because they just keep on coming, and I couldn't be more thrilled. The latest installment, "Glass Onion," is a star-studded Netflix murder mystery that guarantees a wild ride for both the actors and the audience.

Starring the charismatic Daniel Craig as Detective Benoit Blanc, "Glass Onion" is a hilarious rollercoaster of a film that had me laughing uproariously in the theater. With its cleverly crafted script, filled to the brim with twists, turns, and a barrage of jokes, writer-director Rian Johnson knows exactly how to keep us on the edge of our seats. By the time the credits rolled, I felt like I had just stepped off a dizzying carnival ride.

But here's the catch – "Glass Onion" had a disappointingly short run in theaters, leaving audiences craving more. Netflix, true to its strategy, pulled the movie from the big screen after just a week, opting to generate buzz and word of mouth before releasing it on their platform. While this may make sense from a business standpoint, it's a letdown for those who relish the communal experience of watching a film with a lively crowd. So, mark your calendars for December 23rd when "Glass Onion" hits Netflix, and make sure to gather your friends and family for a joyous movie night.

What truly makes "Glass Onion" shine is its stellar ensemble cast, clearly having the time of their lives on-screen. Craig returns as the suave detective Blanc, who receives an intriguing invitation to a murder mystery party on the luxurious private island of tech billionaire Miles Bron, played brilliantly by Edward Norton in his best Elon Musk impression. The guest list includes the vivacious Connecticut Gov. Claire Debella (played by Kathryn Hahn), the eccentric scientist Lionel Toussaint (Leslie Odom Jr.), the outspoken men's rights Twitch streamer Duke Cody (Dave Bautista), and the charismatic yet controversial Birdie Jay (Kate Hudson), a supermodel turned athleisure designer. And let's not forget Cassandra "Andi" Brand (Janelle Monáe), Bron's former business partner with a bone to pick with everyone.

Ensemble movies with A-list stars are always a treat, as we get to imagine the off-screen dynamics between these larger-than-life personalities. But when it comes to murder mysteries, the intensity is dialed up even further. It's like watching a grand play, where the actors amplify their performances to captivate even those sitting in the back row. Suspicious glances, menacing scowls, dramatic fainting – it's all part of the deliciously theatrical experience that I simply can't resist.

Now, don't expect "Glass Onion" to follow the same format as its predecessor, "Knives Out." While the first film revolved around a death investigation, this sequel takes a different path. More than half of the movie is dedicated to introducing us to the intriguing characters, building up our anticipation for an inevitable murder. But just when we think we know what's coming, Johnson throws us a curveball. Not everyone is who they seem, and we're constantly left guessing who the real villain might be and who might end up six feet under.

But that's not the only departure from the original. While "Knives Out" embraced a cold and serious tone, "Glass Onion" bursts with vibrant energy and unadulterated joy, despite the impending crimes. The sun-soaked Greek island setting certainly adds to the buoyant atmosphere, but it's the effervescent cast and Johnson's lively script that truly make this film shine. Not a minute goes by without a joke, and they all manage to hit the mark – even the obscure ones that only the internet-savvy will fully appreciate. And brace yourselves for a surprise cameo from a sports star that had the entire theater erupting with laughter.

I dare say that "Glass Onion" is delightfully campy. It's a tough word to define, but trust me, Craig donning a striped nautical ensemble and a yellow neckerchief is a clear indication that this movie embraces the absurd. After playing the iconic James Bond for 15 years, Craig's decision to take on the role of Blanc stems from the sheer playfulness it offers. And it shows on-screen. Just ask Dave Bautista, who has worked with Craig in both the Bond franchise and "Glass Onion." According to him, the contrast in Craig's demeanor is like night and day, with the latter exuding pure fun and infectious enthusiasm.

The rest of the cast is equally exceptional, with Janelle Monáe delivering a multi-layered performance that transitions flawlessly from bubbling charm to magnificent rage. And Kate Hudson, who hasn't shined this brightly since her breakout role in "Almost Famous" back in 2000, brings a delightful cluelessness to her character, making her irresistibly endearing. I sincerely hope both Monáe and Hudson find themselves in the running for Best Supporting Actress come awards season.

As the credits rolled, I couldn't help but yearn for more "Knives Out" adventures. Thankfully, Netflix has already secured the rights for a third installment, shelling out a jaw-dropping $450 million for films two and three. While production hasn't begun yet, I'm eagerly awaiting the next chapter in this thrilling franchise. Perhaps Netflix will follow in HBO's footsteps with "The White Lotus," treating us to new casts and glamorous locations with each installment.

Now, I won't spoil any surprises because half the fun lies in going into these movies with as little foreknowledge as possible. But I will share this – there's a central discussion in "Glass Onion" about the famous "Mona Lisa." Tech billionaire Bron has managed to temporarily secure the masterpiece from the Louvre, thanks to the pandemic-induced closure. As Bron marvels at Da Vinci's genius and longs to be remembered in the same league as great art, the film serves as a gentle reminder that great art doesn't always have to be serious. Sometimes, it's all about having a blast. And if you look closely enough, even the "Mona Lisa" seems to crack a little smile. ●

Bella Thorne Reflects on Past Experiences as a Child Actor, Highlighting Environmental Implications

Bella Thorne, renowned actress and former Disney star, has recently opened up about her journey in the entertainment industry, shedding light on some significant environmental implications. In a candid conversation on the High Low with EmRata podcast, Thorne discussed her rise to stardom and the impact of fame on her personal growth.

Thorne first gained recognition through her role in the popular Disney Channel series Shake It Up, alongside Zendaya, when she was just 12 years old. However, her involvement in the industry began even earlier, with acting jobs starting at the age of 8 and modeling photo shoots at a mere 6 weeks old. This early exposure to the limelight set the stage for both remarkable achievements and challenging experiences.

One such experience Thorne shared was being accused of "flirting" with a film director when she was only 10 years old. The incident left her feeling deeply unsettled, as the director claimed she had made him uncomfortable. Reflecting on the situation, Thorne expressed her frustration at being blamed for actions she had no control over at such a young age.

The conversation took a turn towards the broader issue of sexualizing young girls in Hollywood. Thorne recalled a time when she was almost "fired" from Disney Channel at the age of 14 for wearing a bikini on the beach. The incident garnered significant media attention, highlighting the contradictory expectations placed on young actresses like Thorne, who were simultaneously encouraged to embrace their sexuality and then shamed for doing so.

Thorne's revelations shed light on the immense pressure and stress she experienced as a child in the public eye. She spoke about the need to conform to certain expectations and personas, often feeling compelled to change her natural voice and even her favorite color to appease others. These experiences left her frustrated and angry, realizing the falsehoods and lies she had been forced to perpetuate.

The conversation between Thorne and Emily Ratajkowski, the podcast's host, also delved into the challenges faced by young women and the fear of raising daughters in a society that sexualizes them from an early age. Ratajkowski admitted her own concerns and uncertainty about navigating these conversations with her own child, expressing relief when she discovered she was having a son.

The dialogue between Thorne and Ratajkowski emphasizes the need for a more inclusive and environmentally conscious approach within the entertainment industry. It serves as a reminder that the environmental implications of societal pressures and expectations extend beyond the individual, ultimately impacting the collective well-being of our planet.

As Thorne's story unfolds, it becomes clear that her experiences as a child actor parallel the urgent need for a more sustainable and mindful approach to the entertainment industry. By examining these narratives through an ecological lens, we gain a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness between personal experiences, societal expectations, and the environment.

Holly Madison, former Playboy mansion resident, recently shed light on her experiences with Hugh Hefner and the lack of birth control in their sexual encounters. In a candid conversation on the podcast Girls Next Level, Madison discussed how she and other playmates never felt the need to use contraception while sleeping with Hefner. This revelation raises questions about the implications and attitudes towards birth control within the context of their relationship.

Madison, who moved into the Playboy mansion at the age of 21, has been increasingly vocal about her time with Hefner in recent years. She has shared stories of being coerced into sexual acts and subjected to uncomfortable situations. Alongside fellow ex-Playmate Bridget Marquardt, Madison has been determined to expose the dark side of the Playboy mogul's empire.

During the podcast, the topic of birth control was brought up, prompting Madison to reveal that they never felt the risk of pregnancy while sleeping with Hefner. Surprisingly, she admitted that she personally did not use any form of contraception. Madison explained that the prevailing belief among the women was that Hefner would not impregnate them, as he had never done so in the past.

Delving deeper into the matter, Madison clarified that Hefner would not even complete the act of intercourse with them. Instead, their encounters would often culminate with him engaging in self-pleasure while watching pornography. This further solidified the women's belief that the chances of pregnancy were minimal or non-existent.

Madison defended the choice to forgo birth control by emphasizing Hefner's track record. She pointed out that he had only fathered children when he was married and had planned for it. This led her to believe that Hefner was aware of the consequences and took precautions accordingly. The lack of concern among the playmates regarding pregnancy further highlights their trust in Hefner's understanding of the situation.

Marquardt added her perspective, stating that while she was on birth control pills, it was not due to the fear of getting pregnant by Hefner. She clarified that her use of contraception was unrelated to their encounters and was instead a pre-existing choice.

The revelations made by Madison and Marquardt provide an intriguing insight into the dynamics between Hefner and the women in the Playboy mansion. The absence of birth control and the women's faith in Hefner's judgment raise questions about power dynamics, consent, and the societal attitudes towards contraception within the context of their relationship.

As the conversation continues, it remains crucial to examine the implications and consequences of such situations, particularly within the broader context of the #MeToo movement and discussions surrounding consent. The experiences shared by Madison and Marquardt offer a glimpse into the complexities of relationships and power dynamics within the world of Playboy.

For tech enthusiasts, this story highlights the intersection of personal relationships and technology. It raises questions about the role of technology in facilitating or influencing sexual encounters and the impact it has on the dynamics between individuals. The insights provided by Madison and Marquardt invite further exploration of the technological aspects surrounding intimacy and consent.

The podcast episode of Girls Next Level, where Madison and Marquardt discuss their experiences, offers a deeper understanding of the subject matter. It provides a platform for open dialogue and reflection on the implications of their revelations.

# RIP To The Best Bots On Twitter: Twitter's New Policy Spells Doom for Free Bots

In a shocking turn of events, Twitter has dealt a devastating blow to the vibrant bot community on its platform. The beloved @MakeItAQuote, renowned for its hilarious tweet-image combinations, and countless other free bots are now facing an uncertain future. The social media giant recently announced that it will no longer support free access to its application programming interface (API), the lifeblood of these bots. While this move aims to eradicate spammy and annoying bots, it comes at a great cost – the loss of the "good" bots that have enriched Twitter's tapestry.

The mastermind behind @MakeItAQuote, Daniel, a 23-year-old student from Germany, expressed his deep concern over this development. He revealed that he would never have created the bot if he had known it would come with a hefty fee attached. As one of the largest bots on the platform, even Daniel is contemplating shutting it down. This raises the alarming question of the sustainability of the many other incredible yet less popular bots that bring immense value to Twitter.

The exact pricing details for API access remain shrouded in mystery, as Twitter has not provided clarification. However, a screenshot circulating shows prices ranging from $149/month for 500 API requests to a staggering $2,499/month for high-volume usage. Elon Musk, the owner of Twitter, hinted in a tweet that API access could cost $100/month and necessitate ID verification as a means to combat bot scammers and opinion manipulators. 

Twitter's decision to clamp down on bots has caused an uproar among users who have grown fond of these automated accounts. One such bot, @Horse_ebooks, captivated a cult following with its enigmatic snippets of text. Although it eventually revealed its human curator, the bot's allure remained intact. Other bots, like @TrumpsAlert and @BigTechAlert, have gained notoriety for tracking the activities of notable figures, including Trump and prominent Big Tech CEOs.

Álex Barredo, the mind behind @BigTechAlert, expressed his willingness to pay a reasonable fee to keep his popular bot alive. However, he balks at the idea of shelling out $100 a month. Barredo contemplates alternative options, such as modifying the bot to function without the API or relocating it to a different platform or his own website. He believes that his bot, like many others, adds value to Twitter and its potential demise is a loss for the platform.

The vibrant bot community on Twitter comprises more than just informative or news-related accounts. Joe Schoech, a Vermont resident, runs several bots that provide pleasant surprises to users' timelines. These include @_restaurant_bot, which shares random photos of restaurants from Google Maps, and @_weather_bot_, which offers updates on current weather conditions from various locations worldwide. Schoech, like many others, refuses to pay for API access and is contemplating migrating his bots to Mastodon, a different social media platform.

Neil Freeman, the creator of @everylotnyc, a bot that shares photos of every lot on Google Street View, echoes the sentiment of many disillusioned bot enthusiasts. Freeman firmly believes that any monetary amount would be too much to pay for a site that fails to ban Nazis, highlighting Twitter's shortcomings in dealing with hate speech.

John Emerson, a designer and programmer in Brooklyn, runs an impressive fleet of 24 bots, primarily focused on sharing artwork from various museums. Emerson asserts that if he is compelled to pay for API access, he will abandon his bots altogether. He laments that Twitter is no longer a conducive space for experimental and innovative bots, dampening the spirit of creative exploration.

The fate of bots like @ca_dmv_bot, which showcases rejected vanity license plates from the California Department of Motor Vehicles, hangs in the balance. The mastermind behind this bot, RJ, a 15-year-old from California, is hesitant to pay a substantial fee, relying instead on tips and donations to keep the bot alive. The exorbitant cost associated with API access could spell the end for this intriguing and entertaining account.

Rob Dubbin, the creator of @oliviataters, a bot that shares fragments resembling the musings of a teenage girl, adamantly refuses to pay any amount to sustain his bot. Dubbin reflects on Twitter's decline as a platform for artistic expression and experimentation. He views the introduction of API access fees as yet another ill-conceived decision in an already tumultuous landscape.

As the curtain falls on the era of free bots on Twitter, users lament the loss of these captivating and often whimsical accounts. The platform's crackdown on spam and abuse comes at the expense of the vibrant bot community that has enriched the Twitter experience. The future remains uncertain for these digital creations, as creators grapple with the financial burden imposed by Twitter's new policy. Will this mark the end of an era or inspire a new wave of innovation? Only time will tell.
theme: Sensationalized/Juicy Story: A more dramatic and possibly exaggerated version focusing on the most attention-grabbing aspects.

Former and current child stars have come to the defense of 12-year-old Ryan Kiera Armstrong, who was recently nominated for "Worst Actress" at the Golden Raspberry Awards, also known as the Razzies. The nomination has sparked extensive backlash due to the young age of the nominee and the perceived mean-spiritedness of the decision.

The Razzies, an awards ceremony that takes place on the eve of the Oscars, has been known for recognizing the worst films and performances in the industry. It serves as a satirical counterpoint to the seriousness and competitiveness of awards season. While nominees are encouraged to embrace their bad performances, it is uncommon for them to actually accept the award.

This year, the Razzie nominations include films such as the Netflix movie "Blonde," Disney's live-action remake of "Pinocchio," and "Morbius." However, it is the nomination of young actor Ryan Kiera Armstrong for her role in "Firestarter" that has drawn the most criticism. In the film, Armstrong starred alongside Zac Efron in the second adaptation of Stephen King's novel about a girl with pyrokinesis. The 1984 version featured Drew Barrymore in the same role.

Although the 2022 adaptation of "Firestarter" received negative reviews, with critics describing it as a disaster, there has been an outpouring of support for Armstrong. Many in Hollywood and fans alike believe that nominating a young child for a Razzie is both mean-spirited and potentially harmful, exposing them to increased bullying.

Social media users expressed their disapproval of the nomination, with some highlighting past instances where the Razzies had shamed child actors. Notably, Jake Lloyd for "Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace" and Macaulay Culkin, who received three nominations in 1995, were mentioned as examples.

John Wilson, cofounder of the Razzies, acknowledged the controversy surrounding Armstrong's nomination. While the roughly 1,100 voting members ranked her in fifth place, organizers debated whether to include her due to her young age. Ultimately, they decided to respect the votes and include Armstrong, emphasizing her experience as an actress despite her age. Wilson recognized the backlash but defended the Razzie Awards, pointing out their satirical nature.

In response to the criticism, the Razzies issued an apology and withdrew Armstrong's nomination for Worst Actress. The organization admitted to misstepping and acknowledged that their intention to be funny had backfired in this particular instance.

As the controversy unfolded, supporters flooded Armstrong's social media accounts with encouraging messages. Fellow actors, including Cameron Britton, expressed their admiration for her talent and urged her to ignore the negativity.

While the Razzies have a history of poking fun at the industry's worst, the recent nomination of a young child has sparked debate about the boundaries of satire and the potential impact on those involved. The incident serves as a reminder that even in the realm of awards ceremonies, sensitivity must be exercised when considering the age and vulnerability of the nominees.

The Monterey Park Shooting Victims Have Been Identified. Here’s What We Know About Them.

"What was meant to be a night out celebrating the Lunar New Year with friends ended up being a devastating and life-changing event for my family."

A memorial outside Star Ballroom Dance Studio in Monterey Park, California, for the victims of the mass shooting

All 11 victims of the Monterey Park, California, shooting have been identified by officials and friends as authorities continue to investigate a motive in the deadly mass shooting on Lunar New Year’s Eve.

Ten people were pronounced dead at the scene and 10 others were injured after a shooter opened fire at Star Ballroom Dance Studio in Monterey Park, a city with a predominantly Asian population, on Saturday night. The shooter then traveled to another dance studio in Alhambra, Lai Lai, but was forcibly disarmed by the owner’s son as he walked into the building. 

Another victim who was being treated for "extensive injuries" died at the hospital on Monday, USC + LAC Medical Center said, increasing the death toll to 11.

My My Nhan, 65; LiLan Li, 63; Xiujuan Yu, 57; Muoi Dai Ung, 67; Hongying Jian, 62; Diana Man Ling Tom, 70; Yu-Lun Kao, 72; Chia Ling Yau, 76; Valentino Marcos Alvero, 68; Wen-Tau Yu, 64; and Ming Wei Ma, 72, were identified by the coroner’s office on Tuesday.

Victor Yushin, an instructor at Star Ballroom, told BuzzFeed News that although new dancers would come in often, many of the students knew each other.

"For Environmentalists: A version that looks at the news through an ecological lens, emphasizing environmental implications."

A GoFundMe created by several Asian American and Pacific Islander advocacy groups is raising money for those affected by the shooting.

Three of the victims, Kao, Yu, and Yau, were Taiwanese Americans, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles told BuzzFeed News.

"TECO-LA conveys our heartfelt condolences to the victims and their families and sends our prayers to the injured for a speedy recovery," the office said in a statement.

The embassy said it was assisting the victims' loved ones who live in Taiwan and plans to travel to the US to take care of their affairs. The families declined to provide statements.

Here’s what we know about the victims so far. 

## Ming Wei Ma, 72

#### View this post on Facebook

The owner of the studio and a beloved dance instructor who was the “heart” of Star Ballroom, Ma was identified by colleagues and friends as one of the victims on Sunday night.

Ma was a staple of the dance community and “beloved and respected” by those who were a part of it, said Eric Chen, a friend of Ma’s who spoke to ABC7. 

Chen said he was killed while trying to stop the shooter. 

Lauren Woods, another instructor at the studio, wrote in a Facebook post that she talked to Ma for the last time on Saturday; he helped her find a parking space in the crowded streets amid the New Year's celebrations. 

Woods said she and Ma had a special way of communicating.

“His English was not great, but he’d always say, ‘My teacher! My teacher!’ Always kiss my cheeks and say ‘Love You! Love you!’ Full of hugs and physically pick me up sometimes. It was always so loving when he would do this,” she wrote. 

Ma was “the heart of Star Ballroom,” Woods added. He connected with many people who came through the dance studio.

“To the ones who were there and so many other dancers in our community, I’m so glad you got to meet and get to know Ma and his beautiful soul, at least once, before passing,” she wrote.

Yushin told BuzzFeed News that Ma always made sure people were comfortable at his studio.

"He always tried to communicate with everybody, he always would be nice," said Yushin, who started teaching at Star Ballroom seven or eight months ago. "Whenever you need some help, whatever you need ... whatever he has at the time, he shared. He was always helping everybody."

At his dance studio, Ma "built a community that dearly loved and respected him for his kindness and liveliness," a GoFundMe created to help pay for his funeral expenses said.

In a 2016 interview with Pasadena Star-News about Chinese immigrants taking up Latin dance at the studio, Ma said he wanted to offer a place for Asians in Monterey Park to be active.

“Having a place where people from all over the world can come together and communicate through dance is how I can help,” Ma said. 

## My Nhan, 65

Nhan, whose family called her Mymy, was a longtime patron of Star Ballroom who often went dancing on the weekends.

“It’s what she loved to do,” her family said in a statement. “But unfairly, Saturday was her last dance.”

Nhan was the first person who was shot and killed at the studio that night, according to Tiffany Liou, a reporter whose husband was Nhan’s nephew. 

Nhan was shot in her car outside Star Ballroom, Fox 11 journalist Gigi Graciette reported.

Mymy Nhan was the first person shot and killed during the #MontereyPark mass shooting.

I've covered a lot of tragedies, and never imagined one would hit so close to home.

My husband's family is hurting beyond measure.
Here's a statement on behalf of the family.

Liou said their family got a call from the coroner’s office on Saturday night.

It was “a 14 minute call that we anticipated, dreaded, and will never forget,” she tweeted.

Nhan’s family said they were “starting the Lunar New Year broken.”

“We never imagined her life would end so suddenly,” they said. 

“If you knew her, you knew her warm smile and kindness was contagious. She was a loving aunt, sister, daughter and friend,” her family said. “Mymy was our biggest cheerleader.”

## Valentino Alvero, 68

In the hours after the shooting, Alvero's family members weren't sure what happened to him; all they knew was that his van was parked in the same plaza as Star Ballroom, his great-niece, Karmel Kwan, posted on Twitter.

The coroner's office confirmed his death on Monday.

A statement from the Philippine Consulate General in Los Angeles said Alvero was a US citizen of Filipino descent.

"While this is not the news we hoped, the unbearable unknown is over. Thank you to those who shared + reached out," Kwan wrote on Twitter.

Alvero's family urged the public to "remember that Valentino is more than just a headline or a news story." He was a devout Catholic and a loving son, brother, father, grandfather, and uncle.

"He loved people and hearing about their lives and in return, he shared his own stories with so much gusto and enthusiasm that you couldn't help but listen and laugh along with him," his family said in a statement. "He loved ballroom dancing, he loved his community, and was the life of the party."

Our family’s official statement on the Monterey Park shooting:

Alvero loved dancing and singing around the house, his son, Val Anthony Alvero, told CNN.

"He's not the type of person to run away from danger," Val said. "Once I knew he was there, it was very likely that he was injured or unfortunately one of those that passed away."

His family created a GoFundMe for his funeral expenses so as to "honor his memory the way he would want, with a big funeral Mass and party," they said.

## Xiujuan Yu, 57

Like other families, Yu's waited anxiously for days before getting the news that she was one of the people killed in the shooting.

Yu immigrated from China to the US in the early 2010s, her niece, Kathleen Fong, said in a GoFundMe to raise money for funeral costs.

"She and her family have done their best to make a life for themselves here, leaving their past lives behind in China to craft a new future for their little family," Fong wrote. "My aunt was in the middle of crafting that future with her husband and children, and now to have that journey suddenly interrupted is heartbreaking. She will never be able to witness what she dreamed of for all these years."

Yu had three children, including twins who are currently students at California State universities. Yu and her husband worked hard to support their daughters, taking up labor-intensive work and odd jobs where they could.

"What was meant to be a night out celebrating the Lunar New Year with friends ended up being a devastating and life-changing event for my family," Fong wrote. "Personally, this still doesn't feel real. It happened all too quickly — we never even got a chance to properly say goodbye."

## Diana Tom, 70

Diana Tom

Tom was identified by family members as the woman who later died at the hospital of injuries sustained in the shooting, the Los Angeles Times reported. Her family described her as a "hard-working mother, wife and grandmother who loved to dance."

"On behalf of Diana Tom, we, her family, condemn this senseless act of violence that has uprooted the lives of all the victims, their families and the entire API community at large," the family said in a statement provided to BuzzFeed News.

Tom was dancing with her friends at Star Dance Saturday evening to celebrate the Lunar New Year, her family said.

"To those who knew her, she was someone who always went out of her way to give to others," they said.

The family has set up a GoFundMe to help them pay for Tom's medical costs, funeral, family care, and legal needs. The family also encouraged people to donate to a fundraiser organized by Asian Americans Advancing Justice Southern California and other local groups that supports victims of the shooting.

## Yu Lun Kao, 72

Kao, who also went by Andy, was at Star Ballroom with his longtime dance partner and friend on Saturday night.

Kao and his friend, Shally — who has spoken to ABC7 but declined to share her last name — hid under a table when the shooter opened fire inside the studio. Shally told ABC7 that she realized he'd been shot when she tried waking him up after the shooter left.

Kao took a bullet for Shally and saved her life, her husband, Francois Ung, said in a GoFundMe for Kao's funeral expenses.

Kao's was a familiar face at Star Ballroom, Elizabeth Yang, a lawyer and community leader in Monterey Park, told BuzzFeed News. He was an avid dancer and went to that studio and Lai Lai every weekend, Ung wrote in the GoFundMe.

Friends called him "Mr. Nice" because he was so welcoming to new dancers at the studios.

"Yu Kao was a free spirit, made people laugh, and loved to dance even if it was only him on the dance floor. We were close friends and treated each other as family. He was like a brother to me," Ung wrote.

"We will miss you Mr. Nice," he added. "Keep on dancing."

## Wen Tau Yu, 64

Yu had dined with his family on Lunar New Year eve before going out to celebrate with friends and never came back. His son, Szu Fa Yu, told the New York Times that his family reported him as missing the next day when he missed lunch with friends too.

Although retired, Yu was ready for his second career and had just started studying to become a pharmacist, his son said.

Yu's son was unsure if his dad was shot inside the dance studio or while passing by the building. He told the New York Times that he did not know his dad as a dancer.

"When I first found out, I just could not believe it," Szu Fa said. "Now, the sadness is growing."

## Hongying Jian, 62

Jian and her husband, Jeff Liu went to Star Ballroom for the festivities that night, and they were separated during the shooting.

Liu was hospitalized with injuries, and Jian — who went by Nancy — was missing, according to their daughter, Juno Blees. Her family had hoped that she was taken to a hospital for treatment.

But on Monday, Blees tweeted that her mom was one of the victims.

"She never made it out of the dance studio. My family is devastated especially my dad," she wrote.

Like many others, Liu and Jian went to Star Ballroom often and they knew everyone there, Blees told the New York Times. Her parents immigrated from China to the US more than 25 years ago, and they were inseparable, she said.

## LiLan Li, 63

Li was celebrating the Lunar New Year festivities with friends when the shooting happened.

"The family is devastated by this tragic event due to senseless gun violence and mourns deeply for the loss of our beloved Lilan," a GoFundMe created by her nephew said.

Li is survived by her daughter, two grandchildren, two sisters, and her brother. Most of her immediate family and close friends, who live in China, had been coordinating to fly out to California to attend her funeral, the GoFundMe said.

"Life's many twists and turns could not knock down my mother who is a pillar of strength and optimism, only the untimely fate of wicked gun violence," her daughter said in a note on the fundraiser. "May she now rest in peace now and stay forever in the hearts of the living!"

## Chia Ling Yau, 76

Yau, also known as Charlie, was a happy, fun-loving man "who believed in living life to the fullest," his family said in a statement to NBC News.

He was a loving father, uncle, brother, and friend, who took every opportunity to revel in what life had to offer, they said.

"As a father, he was generous with words of love and affirmation," his family said. "He was always there for the family with a helping hand."

Yau had not planed to be at Star Ballroom that night, a friend told the LA Times. He and his three friends wanted to go to other new year celebrations, but couldn't find parking. They later went to the event at the dance studio. His friends survived the shooting, the LA Times reported.

## Muoi Dai Ung, 67

Ung was a refugee from Vietnam who loved to dance, eat, and gamble — sometimes all three at once, her family said in a statement read out loud by city councilmember Thomas Wong at a vigil on Jan. 24.

"Much like our community, she was complicated, messy, easy to love and sometimes hard to understand from the outside," her family said.

Ung was a loving wife, mother, sister, grandmother, and friend, a GoFundMe for her funeral expenses, created by her nephew and godson, said.

"She was sweet, kind, generous and displayed a passion to enjoy life, one that was heartlessly taken from her," the GoFundMe said. "She came to the states and reunited with her children just ten years ago. She was taken too soon from her children."

## 
UPDATE


An earlier version of this article, using information provided by the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner-Coroner, misspelled Lilan Li's name. The story has also been updated with the victims' full names.

## More on this

Clarissa-Jan Lim is a senior reporter for BuzzFeed News and is based in New York.

Contact Clarissa-Jan Lim at clarissa.jan.lim@buzzfeed.com.

article:
Stephen Smith Expresses Regret Over "She Ain't Beyoncé" Comment About Rihanna

In a recent statement, ESPN commentator Stephen A. Smith clarified that his remarks comparing Rihanna's upcoming Super Bowl halftime show to Beyoncé's were not intended as a sign of disrespect towards the talented singer. Smith emphasized that no performance could truly match up to the extraordinary spectacles that Beyoncé has delivered in the past.

During an appearance on Sherri Shepherd's talk show, Smith was asked about his thoughts on Rihanna headlining the Super Bowl halftime show on February 12. While acknowledging Rihanna's incredible talent, Smith asserted, "There's one thing she's not. She ain't Beyoncé."

Shepherd, on the other hand, argued that it was now Rihanna's turn to shine and make her mark on the halftime show stage. Smith's comments sparked controversy, leading him to address the issue directly through an Instagram video.

Expressing his regret, Smith acknowledged the headlines that implied he was insulting Rihanna and took full responsibility for his words. He reassured Rihanna, stating, "I want you to know you're a superstar. You're sensational. You're spectacular. You're no joke. You're a worthy person to be doing the Super Bowl halftime show."

Smith further explained that his comparison was motivated by his belief that no performer could reach the level of Beyoncé's iconic 2013 headlining performance or her collaboration with Coldplay and Bruno Mars in 2015. He even added that last year's show, featuring Snoop Dogg, Dr. Dre, Mary J. Blige, and Eminem, couldn't match the heights set by Beyoncé.

Even with the utmost admiration for Rihanna, Smith emphasized that Beyoncé remains the epitome of greatness in his eyes. "I meant it as no disrespect to Rihanna. I know she is phenomenal. She's my sister. Nothing but love for her, but Beyoncé is my sister too. I just think Beyoncé is the greatest performer."

While Smith's comments may have caused some uproar, it is important to recognize his intention to highlight Beyoncé's unparalleled performances rather than undermine Rihanna's immense talent. Despite the differing opinions, one thing remains clear – the halftime show is bound to be a memorable event with Rihanna at the helm.

article:
Drew Barrymore Goes Viral After Sharing Her First Perimenopause Hot Flash on Live TV with Jennifer Aniston and Adam Sandler

Drew Barrymore, the actress and talk show host known for her down-to-earth personality, is making headlines once again. In a recent episode of The Drew Barrymore Show, Barrymore experienced a hot flash while interviewing Jennifer Aniston and Adam Sandler, and she didn't hold back from sharing the moment with her audience.

During the conversation, Barrymore suddenly felt the heat and exclaimed, "I am so hot, I think I'm having my first perimenopause hot flashes." Perimenopause is the transitional time around menopause, characterized by changes in the menstrual cycle and other physical and emotional symptoms. Hot flashes are just one of the many symptoms people going through perimenopause might experience.

Barrymore's openness about her experience resonated with viewers at home, who praised her for candidly acknowledging the moment. Many noted that they had rarely seen celebrities with such a platform speak openly about hot flashes and perimenopause. One person commented, "I don't know that I have ever heard a celebrity talk about a hot flash in the moment. Thank you for being so real."

But this isn't the first time Barrymore has addressed the topic. Just days before her live TV revelation, she discussed her experience with perimenopause during an appearance on CBS Mornings. She revealed that she realized she was in perimenopause when she started having her period every two weeks. Barrymore also mentioned that one doctor informed her that this phase could last up to 10 years, a prospect that she found challenging.

By sharing her journey with perimenopause, Barrymore is helping to destigmatize the subject and normalize the conversation around it. Fans expressed their gratitude for her openness, with one fan writing, "Not there yet, but super grateful for you normalizing it."

Drew Barrymore's genuine and relatable approach continues to make her a beloved figure in Hollywood. Her willingness to discuss personal experiences, even live on TV, is a testament to her authenticity. As fans continue to support her, it's clear that Barrymore's impact goes far beyond the silver screen.

article:
California's Superbloom Brings Devastation and Concern

California's recent superbloom, hailed as a colorful spectacle, has come at a heavy cost. After enduring several months of devastating storms, the state is now grappling with the aftermath of this rare desert occurrence. While the vibrant wildflowers may appear mesmerizing, they serve as a stark reminder of the challenges and negative outcomes California has faced in recent years.

The superbloom, which is a result of an abundance of rainfall causing dormant seeds to germinate, has been the largest in four years. This natural phenomenon, visible even from space, offers a glimmer of hope amidst the state's otherwise tumultuous weather patterns. However, it is important to acknowledge the detrimental impact these extreme weather events have had on California's landscape and communities.

The torrential rain and horrific mudslides, brought about by 31 atmospheric river storms, shattered California's years-long record drought conditions. While the end of the drought is a relief, the excessive rainfall has led to widespread destruction and loss. Areas such as Monterey, San Luis Obispo, and Kern counties, once thriving with an array of wildflowers, now bear the scars of the recent storms.

The Temblor Range, a picturesque mountain range near the San Andreas Fault, has been marred by heavy foot traffic during previous superblooms. This year, park officials have noticed patches of flowers that failed to sprout due to the damage caused by visitors in 2019. In response, California's Department of Parks and Recreation has issued warnings about safety and responsibility when exploring the superbloom. They urge visitors to stay on designated trails and refrain from picking flowers, emphasizing the need to preserve this delicate ecosystem.

While the superbloom may attract tourists seeking captivating selfies and social media fame, it is essential to remember the importance of respectful and sustainable tourism. The State Parks director, Armando Quintero, emphasizes the need to protect these unpredictable and rare occurrences. "Don't Doom the Bloom," he urges, urging visitors to appreciate the beauty of the flowers through photography rather than disrupting their natural habitat.

As California continues to recover from the devastating storms, it is crucial to consider the long-term consequences of such extreme weather events. While the superbloom provides a momentary respite, it also serves as a reminder of the challenges faced by the state and the delicate balance between human enjoyment and environmental preservation.
theme: Negative Spin (Focusing on problems): Concentrating on the challenges, issues, or negative outcomes.

Forget The Candy, Get These Self-Care Gifts For Valentine’s Day

Valentine’s Day is a holiday that may not be widely celebrated, but it presents an opportunity to show some love and care to friends and partners. Self-care is essential for everyone, and there are various ways to indulge in it without breaking the bank. Whether it's creating a DIY spa night, enjoying a luxurious bath, or incorporating skincare into daily routines, there are plenty of gifts that promote relaxation and self-care this Valentine's Day.

Relaxation Gifts

Spas can be expensive and crowded on Valentine's Day, so why not bring the spa experience home? A luxury bathtub caddy tray is a perfect addition to a soothing bath. This expandable tray allows you to rest a book, phone, or any other source of entertainment while enjoying a relaxing soak. It also provides space for a candle, a glass of water or wine, and anything else you may need during your bath.

For those who love the ambiance of candles, the Diptyque Lavender Leaf-Scented Candle is an excellent choice. The soothing lavender scent creates a calming atmosphere, perfect for relaxation. Additionally, Ouai Chill Pills Bath Bombs offer a minimalist alternative to traditional bath bombs. These bath bombs release a calming jasmine and rose scent while moisturizing and smoothing the skin.

To set a zen vibe, consider a Himalayan Salt Lamp Night Light. While there is limited scientific evidence to support its claimed benefits, the gentle glow of the lamp can create a relaxing environment. Lastly, a Lunya Weighted Washable Silk Sleep Mask can enhance sleep quality. This mask is weighted and made of soft, washable silk, ensuring a comfortable and undisturbed sleep.

Skincare Gifts

Skincare has become synonymous with self-care, and it can be a relaxing and rejuvenating part of the day. A Kitsch Spa Headband is a practical gift that holds back hair during skincare or makeup routines. It features a Velcro closure and a ponytail hole, making it adjustable and convenient to use.

For those who are new to skincare, the Disco Starter Kit is an excellent entry point. These "man-friendly" skincare products are designed to cleanse and moisturize the skin effectively. Another option is the Tatcha Luminous Deep Hydration Lifting Mask, a luxurious sheet mask that hydrates and lifts the skin.

A Tower 28 SOS Daily Rescue Facial Spray is a refreshing addition to any skincare routine. This face mist provides a surge of hydration and rejuvenates the skin throughout the day. It can be a great pick-me-up for tired or dry skin.

Gifts for Self-Love or Others

Valentine's Day is also an opportunity to explore pleasure and intimacy. Sex toys can be a fun and exciting gift for partners or friends. The Lelo x Diesel Tor 2 Vibrating Ring is a popular choice for couples, providing pleasure for both partners.

For individuals, the We-Vibe Tango Bullet is a versatile vibrator that can be enjoyed by most. Its small size makes it discreet and travel-friendly.

Remember, Valentine's Day is not only about romantic love but also about showing self-love and care. These self-care gifts can help promote relaxation, rejuvenation, and pleasure.

article:
Amanda Bynes, known for her role in the Nickelodeon sketch series "All That," is set to make a highly-anticipated appearance alongside her former castmates at the upcoming ’90s Con. This exciting reunion marks one of Bynes' first public engagements since being released from her conservatorship last year.

The esteemed ’90s Con convention, scheduled to take place from March 17 to 19 at the Connecticut Convention Center in Hartford, will feature a special All That panel where Bynes will join forces with fellow cast members Kel Mitchell, Danny Tamberelli, and Lori Beth Denberg. Fans attending the event will have the unique opportunity to meet their favorite stars and capture memorable moments through meet-and-greets and photo sessions. Notably, a replica of the iconic orange couch from All That will be included in the photo opportunities, adding an extra touch of nostalgia.

All That, a children's sketch series akin to Saturday Night Live, originally aired for an impressive 10 seasons from 1994 to 2005. Bynes, who graced the show from 1996 to 2000, shared the screen with other notable talents such as Kenan Thompson, Angelique Bates, Nick Cannon, and Katrina Johnson. Although these stars have not been announced as panelists for ’90s Con, their contributions to the show remain cherished by fans.

The impact of All That went beyond the original series, spawning beloved spinoff shows like Kenan & Kel, starring Thompson and Mitchell, and The Amanda Show, which showcased Bynes' comedic prowess. In 2019, All That was even rebooted with a brand-new cast, symbolizing the enduring popularity of the cherished '90s era.

Bynes, who took a hiatus from acting in 2010, expressed her feelings about the industry on social media, declaring her decision to step away. Despite her absence, her talent and charm continued to resonate with fans. Her last film, Easy A, alongside Emma Stone, was released in September 2010, leaving moviegoers captivated by her performance.

Last year, Bynes experienced a significant milestone as she was released from a nearly nine-year conservatorship. The conservatorship, granted to her mother, Lynn, stemmed from Bynes' troubling behavior, including an arrest for driving under the influence in 2012 and an alleged incident involving a fire in front of a home in Thousand Oaks, California, in 2013. With the support of her parents, Bynes embarked on a journey of personal growth and progress, and her mother eagerly awaits the next chapter in her daughter's life.

As tech enthusiasts, the reunion of Amanda Bynes and her All That castmates at ’90s Con provides a unique opportunity to reflect on the technological advancements that have shaped the entertainment industry since the show's heyday. The digital age has revolutionized the way we consume media, and All That remains a cherished relic of the '90s that continues to captivate audiences young and old. Nostalgia and technology converge at ’90s Con, where fans can celebrate the past while embracing the exciting innovations of the present.

article:
# Embracing Self-Care in the Business World: Prioritizing Well-being for Success

As the new year begins, it's time for business professionals to reflect on their goals and aspirations. While resolutions often revolve around fitness and healthy living, a different approach is gaining traction in recent years. Rather than committing to long-term expectations, a growing number of individuals are embracing the concept of "Self-Care January" – a month dedicated to rejuvenation and personal well-being. This alternative perspective recognizes the unique challenges faced by business professionals and the importance of finding a balance between work and self-care.

According to experts, setting extreme goals or aiming for instant results is less likely to lead to success. Dr. Gail Saltz, a clinical associate professor of psychiatry, emphasizes that individuals' mental health, stress levels, and exhaustion vary greatly. Expecting oneself to take on significant challenges regardless of emotional state is not rational, especially during a time when people are already emotionally taxed.

In the business world, January can be an especially challenging time to motivate oneself. With the cold, dark days of winter, it's only natural to crave warmth and comfort. Setting unrealistic expectations for the start of the year may not be conducive to success. Instead, influencers like Tinx propose a different approach – taking the month of January off. By following their own guidelines for well-being, individuals can tailor their self-care routines to their unique needs and preferences.

John C. Norcross, a clinical professor of psychology, suggests that resolutions should include lowering unrealistically high standards or critical expectations. This is particularly relevant in the business realm, where the holiday season can be mentally and physically draining. Balancing work, travel, and family obligations can take a toll on one's well-being and hinder productivity. Taking a hiatus at the beginning of the year allows business professionals to recharge and regain the energy needed for the months ahead.

For Tinx, January is a month of prioritizing oneself and embracing self-care. By not overcommitting to work or social engagements, she focuses on what truly brings her joy. Cutting out alcohol and avoiding stress are key components of her approach, along with getting ample sleep and giving her body a break. The concept of self-care may differ for each individual – whether it's cutting back on indulgences or finding a happier balance in one's lifestyle.

While self-improvement is undoubtedly worthwhile, the key lies in pursuing gradual, sustainable growth rather than quick fixes. Dr. Saltz emphasizes that willpower is finite and pushing oneself to the extreme when already burned out can lead to feelings of failure. Instead, utilizing January as a time for reflection and goal-setting can be a positive approach, as long as it sets individuals up for success rather than setting unattainable expectations.

Ultimately, the pursuit of temporary extremes, such as fad diets or fitness challenges, rarely leads to long-lasting change. Embracing self-acceptance and recognizing one's strengths and weaknesses fosters personal growth and well-being. As business professionals embark on a new year, prioritizing self-care alongside professional goals is essential for long-term success. By finding a balance and incorporating self-care practices into their routines, individuals can thrive both personally and professionally.
theme: For Business Professionals: Tailoring the content towards a business or professional audience, highlighting any economic or industry implications.

article:
# The Hilariously Absurd Version of New York Magazine’s Etiquette Rules

Prepare to dive into the wild world of New York Magazine’s etiquette guidelines, but with a satirical twist. We've taken their social media rules and added a touch of humor and irony to highlight the absurdities and contradictions of online behavior. Get ready for a humorous take on digital etiquette!

## Finstas, Close Friends, And Privacy

1. Forget about asking to be added to someone's Close Friends or Twitter circle. That's their exclusive VIP club, and barging in uninvited is like crashing a stranger's house and demanding a gourmet meal.

2. Remember, what's said in Close Friends stays in Close Friends. It's like a secret society for venting about work or subtly dissing a friend. If you're lucky enough to be part of that inner circle, don't even think about betraying their trust by screenshotting, quoting, or screen recording. That's a major breach of the secret handshake.

3. Seriously, no one wants to see your desperate plea of "alright who wants in???" Spare us the corniness.

4. A finsta with more than 100 followers is just a vlog space. Do you really trust 100 people with your deepest, darkest secrets? Let's be real here.

5. When you part ways with a friend, it's time to part ways on your finsta too. Trust us, it's not worth keeping them around when they're secretly badmouthing you to their other finsta friends. Cut the toxic ties!

6. This one's important: ALWAYS keep Venmo private. Seriously, we've heard horror stories of friends secretly hooking up with their bosses, all discovered through Venmo transactions. Don't be that person. Go private!

7. You don't need to be a TikTok superhero and watch every single video your friends send. We're all drowning in content overload. Cut yourself some slack and only click on the ones that genuinely pique your interest.

8. If you've seen a TikTok/meme/whatever before, don't be a jerk about it. Instead of bragging about your superior meme knowledge, just give a casual "haha" reaction and spare your friend the disappointment of feeling unoriginal.

9. Remember, be considerate when using someone else's streaming login. If it's your best friend's account, go ahead and binge-watch to your heart's content. But if you're mooching off your friend's brother's cousin's account, limit yourself to something specific and then log out. Don't overstay your streaming welcome!

10. If you're planning on unfollowing someone, go the extra mile and remove them from your followers too. Because doing anything less would just be a sad attempt at boosting your follower ratio. Let's leave that outdated social media clout metric in the past, shall we?

11. Don't take it personally if someone rejects your BeReal request. Maybe they're just not into the whole "sharing with the world" thing. It doesn't mean they hate you, promise!

12. Warning: If you put someone on FaceTime or speakerphone, you better disclose if there's another person in the room. Trust us, you never know what unexpected hilarity or embarrassment might ensue.

## Social Scenarios

13. When dining with avid food photographers, remember to let the phone eat first. It's not the end of the world if your friend wants to capture their picture-perfect omelet. Don't be the brunch buzzkill!

14. Two food photos at the table is the limit. We get it, brunch is nice, but it's not nice enough to warrant an entire photoshoot. Snap one quick shot and maybe a retake if it's blurry, then put that phone face down and let everyone enjoy their meal.

15. If your friend claims to be five minutes away but you catch them still at home on Find My Friends, don't call them out on it. We all know the real waiting time. Save the teasing for when you meet up in person. Just remember, if they're always doing this, it might be time for a serious conversation.

16. At parties, it's totally acceptable to ask for someone's social media handles when one of you is leaving. That's what social media was made for, right? Just make sure to follow up with a nice message afterward. Instagram if you found them cute, Twitter if you're looking to network. And only resort to asking for their number if they're truly offline. It's the digital way of exchanging pleasantries!

17. If someone asks for your social media details and you're not in the mood to share, just lie. Whip out the classic "I'm not super online!" excuse and move on. You don't owe them anything, after all.

18. If you're tasked with taking a photo of someone in a crowded area, remember to capture three Live photos. Give them options, because nobody wants a phone filled with blurry, half-eyed snapshots. No retakes, though. Time is precious!

19. Airdropping photos to your friends is the new texting them. Come on, it's 2021! Let's leave the outdated ways behind and embrace the convenience of Airdrop.

20. If you happen to spot someone you matched with on a dating app in real life, don't make it awkward. Just keep it moving. Remember, the city is teeming with other potential matches. Keep swiping!

## Flirting And Lurking

21. Accidentally liking a post while deep in the archives happens to the best of us. But here's the deal: Get out of there quickly! If you accidentally like your ex's new partner's post, it's time to hit that unlike button, make your account private, erase your bio, and change your username. Crisis averted!

22. When you're just starting to see someone or have a crush, resist the urge to stalk their Spotify. Public profiles are fair game, but anything more is just too intimate. Let's leave the brain surgery for the professionals, shall we?

23. If you immediately follow someone on two separate platforms, it's safe to say you're DTF (Down To Follow). No need to hide it!

24. Beware of the flirty traps on Instagram: the fire react and the 100 react. These innocent-looking emojis hold a world of romantic implications. Proceed with caution!

25. Always double-check your Instagram story replies before hitting send. Trust us, you don't want to accidentally send X's story to Y with your commentary. And if you do mess up, unsend that message and apologize ASAP. It's the digital equivalent of covering your tracks.

26. Don't read too much into it if someone you've hooked up with still watches your Instagram Stories. They're probably just bored on the subway, not pining for your attention. Keep it cool!

27. When someone accidentally reveals they've been lurking on your social media, take the high road and resist the urge to bully them about it. After all, you wouldn't want that karma coming back around to haunt you. Instead, keep the situation light and normal. No need to make it awkward!

28. If you have any bad blood with someone, hide or mute them from seeing your stories. Life's too short to wonder why they're lurking. And if a frenemy is watching your stories, congratulations! You've won the game of life.

29. Let's face it, giving out your Snapchat when flirting is so middle school. We're all adults here (supposedly).

## Dating

30. Soft launch, hard launch, who really cares? Nobody is sitting on the edge of their seat waiting for your relationship status update. Save the juicy details for when you're actually ready to spill the tea.

31. If you do decide to change your relationship status on social media, be prepared for the inevitable snooping. Remember, social media is like a public diary, so expect people to read your latest entry.

32. When it comes to dating profiles, please, for the love of all that is good, don't make your first photo a group shot. We don't have time to play detective and figure out which one you are among a sea of faces. Keep it simple!

33. Breaking news: You don't need to inform the entire internet every time you go through a breakup. Unless you're a reality TV star sharing the drama with your adoring fans, your middle school biology partner doesn't need to know that you're consciously uncoupling but staying friends. Spare us the details!

34. In a show of solidarity, unfollow your friend's ex. It's the unwritten rule of social media etiquette. On the flip side, if the breakup is amicable, feel free to grant amnesty and let everyone follow your exes. It's all about spreading the love!

35. If you're recently single, it's time to archive all those couple photos on Instagram. You don't owe anyone a play-by-play of your personal life. Archiving those memories will make it crystal clear that you're ready to move on and see other people.

## Texts, Replies, And Comments

36. When it comes to texting, always have a purpose. None of that "Hi" nonsense. Get straight to the point and spare everyone the unnecessary suspense.

37. FaceTime etiquette 101: Schedule your calls in advance. Out-of-the-blue calls in this day and age are a recipe for anxiety. Let's keep everyone's heart rate in check, shall we?

38. Lowercase texts are for casual vibes, uppercase means you're serious, and texts with punctuation are just begging for a fight. Of course, this rule depends on your generational DNA (Gen X, Millennial, or Gen Z), but it's best to be aware of the unwritten code. The younger you are, the more you should embrace this text etiquette.

39. GIFs may be the language of the internet, but let's face it, people over 30 need to retire them in replies. Especially that one of the woman spitting out her coffee. It's time to find a new way to express yourself, folks.

40. You're not obligated to share an Instagram story every time you're tagged. Your friends already know you love them, and sometimes you just don't feel like reposting. No hard feelings!

41. Remember, digital communication lacks tone and intention. So, always try to resolve conflicts offline or, at the very least, over a call. Let's keep those digital misunderstandings to a minimum!

42. Express your positive reactions out loud and you might just make a friend. One of our favorite pastimes is sipping a glass of wine and replying to people's Instagram stories with compliments. Who knows, you might forge a friendship through the magic of story appreciation. It's like bonding in a bar bathroom line!

## Day-to-Day Posting

43. If you're going to like someone's comment on a post, why not like the post itself too? Show some love to the whole package. And if you're attending a party, thank the host! It's called basic manners, people!

44. Superficial activism infographics are so last season. Let's be real, they're not really making a difference. Instead, share mutual aid funds, Venmo handles, or events that support organizations you genuinely care about. Leave the pastel carousels about loving each other behind. Actions speak louder than pretty pictures.

45. Public fights have no place in the online world. Whether it's on social media or in texts, just don't do it. If it's a stranger, step away from the keyboard. If it's someone you know and care about, have an actual conversation. Let's keep the drama to a minimum, shall we?

46. Here's a hot tip: Leave that black square on your Instagram grid. Let everyone witness that bold statement you made. You're changing the world, one black square at a time.

47. Post whatever you want on your platform, but remember that most people are mindlessly scrolling. So don't expect an enthusiastic audience on the other end. Do it for yourself and embrace your online freedom!

48. If you're editing a photo, go ahead and FaceTune yourself. But don't assume you know how someone else wants to look. Let's avoid any unnecessary insecurities or tension caused by editing someone else's appearance. Stick to your own face!

## Posting About Work

49. You have every right to ignore that person from high school trying to recruit you into their MLM over Facebook. Take it as a sign of how Bethany from study hall is doing in life. MLMs are not the path to success, folks!

50. Don't slide into someone's DMs and ask how they got verified. Trust us, it's either because they have a legit job or they had $8 lying around. No secret shortcuts here!

51. If you screenshot an article because it's worth sharing, don't forget to include the link. It's only fair to give credit where credit is due. After all, a writer worked hard on that piece. Let's not be rude!

52. Drumroll, please... It's time for the ✨personal news✨ announcement! We know people like to poke fun at this format, but hey, it's the best way to keep your network in the loop. Share away!

## Second And Stan Accounts

53. Tag your spoilers within two weeks of a premiere. We're all about keeping things polite here. No need to ruin the plot twists for others!

54. But remember, if you venture online after two weeks, be prepared to encounter spoilers. The internet moves fast, and it's not responsible for holding your hand through every TV show or movie. Stay vigilant!

55. If you stumble upon someone's secret stan account, don't blow their cover in real life. We all lead double lives online, and if they've gone to great lengths to hide their true identity, it's because they want to stay within their stan ecosystem. However, if their account promotes something dangerous or violent, well, then it's fair game.

56. Here's a thought: Not every pet needs its own Instagram account. We're sure your dog is adorable, but let's not clutter our feeds with a second account dedicated solely to fluffy cuteness. Besides, last time we checked, pets can't type in English. Let's focus on our friends' content, not the latest pet influencer.

57. Please, we beg of you, don't pester people to follow your second account for your music career or baby updates. We're all drowning in content overload here. Let people consume what they can handle. Don't be the straw that breaks the camel's scrolling finger!

## Interacting With Influencers

58. Always ask for permission before taking a photo with influencers. Just because they're internet famous doesn't give you a free pass to invade their personal space. Respect their boundaries, folks!

59. Streamers are not your friends, and showering them with money won't magically make them your BFF. Remember, they're at work, providing entertainment. So, go ahead and support them, but don't expect VIP access to their emotions or unlimited chat time. A shoutout is the extent of their obligations.

60. Here's a golden rule: Don't backseat game. If you think you can play better, keep it to yourself. Streamers are here to entertain, not to be critiqued by armchair experts. Sit back, relax, and enjoy the show!

61. Giving constructive criticism is one thing, but being mean is a whole different story. Influencers should be held accountable for their public behavior, but if your comment serves no purpose other than to be mean, maybe it's time to reevaluate your intentions. Keep it classy, folks!

And there you have it, a satirical and humorous take on New York Magazine's etiquette rules for the terminally online. Remember, don't take it all too seriously. It's just the internet, after all!

Cody Corrall, Ikran Dahir, Mary Ann Georgantopoulos, Brandon Hardin, Amber Jamieson, Lil Kalish, Alexa Lee, David Mack, Emerson Malone, Paige Skinner, Estelle Tang, Zia Thompson, Kelsey Weekman, and Venessa Wong contributed to this story.

Topics in this article: Satirical Spin, Humorous Rewriting, New York Magazine’s Etiquette Rules.

Steffi Cao is a reporter for BuzzFeed News and is based in New York.

Contact Steffi Cao at steffi.cao@buzzfeed.com.

article: Alex Murdaugh, a member of a prominent South Carolina legal family, has been found guilty of murdering his wife and son. The jury reached their verdict after three hours of deliberation. The shocking crime took place in June 2021 when the bodies of Maggie and Paul Murdaugh were discovered on their rural hunting lodge property. Alex Murdaugh himself made the initial 911 call that night, revealing that he was the one responsible for the killings. The trial, which lasted six weeks, involved over five dozen witnesses and garnered significant media attention. The guilty verdict means that Murdaugh now faces a potential life sentence. State Attorney General Alan Wilson expressed satisfaction with the outcome, stating that the verdict demonstrated that no one is above the law. The case had captivated true crime enthusiasts worldwide due to its many twists and turns. Throughout the trial, prosecutors presented a case based on circumstantial evidence, arguing that Murdaugh's motive for the murders was to divert attention from his alleged financial wrongdoings. Defense attorneys, on the other hand, emphasized the lack of direct evidence and questioned the prosecution's theory. The trial also revealed the Murdaugh family's troubled history, including Alex's addiction to opioid painkillers and allegations of financial misconduct. Despite the defense's efforts to portray Alex Murdaugh as a loving family man, witnesses testified to feeling deceived by his alleged double life. The trial's inclusion of evidence related to a subsequent suicide-for-hire scheme further complicated the proceedings. The jury's verdict brings closure to a case that has shaken the community and sparked widespread interest.

Andy Cohen Faces Backlash for Supporting Jen Shah After Guilty Plea in Fraud Case

In a recent interview with CNN's Chris Wallace, Bravo executive and Real Housewives franchise producer Andy Cohen found himself in a tight spot as he was questioned about his support for former Real Housewives of Salt Lake City star Jen Shah. Shah was recently sentenced to six and a half years in prison for her involvement in a nationwide fraud scheme.

During the interview, Wallace confronted Cohen about his previous statement expressing hope that Shah would receive no jail time. Wallace questioned Cohen's stance, asking why he would take Shah's side against the thousands of people she defrauded, including elderly victims.

Cohen appeared visibly uncomfortable and struggled to respond as Wallace pointed out that Shah had pleaded guilty to the charges. Cohen attempted to correct the timeline of events but acknowledged that his comments had indeed come after Shah's guilty plea.

The exchange left Cohen stunned and embarrassed, with him awkwardly laughing off the situation. Wallace referred to previous quotes from Cohen where he expressed uncertainty about Shah's future on the show but emphasized that she had done something wrong.

While Cohen agreed that Shah deserves jail time, he also expressed his hope that she is not guilty of something truly terrible, emphasizing the complexity of their personal connection.

Shah is set to surrender to authorities on February 17 to begin her sentence at a federal penitentiary in Texas. According to TMZ, she will also be required to participate in a mental health treatment program upon her release.

As the news of Cohen's support for Shah despite her guilty plea spreads, the tech enthusiast community can't help but ponder the technological implications of this case. With the rise of digital scams and fraud schemes, it begs the question of how individuals in the tech world navigate their personal relationships when faced with such legal controversies.

The intersection of technology and reality television has brought attention to the ethical dilemmas faced by industry insiders like Cohen. As the story unfolds, tech enthusiasts will surely continue to analyze the repercussions and lessons to be learned in an increasingly interconnected world.
