article:
# Shocking Revelation: Kim Kardashian's St. Patrick's Day Pub Crawl Exposed!

In a turn of events that has left fans stunned, the truth behind Kim Kardashian's seemingly relatable St. Patrick's Day pub crawl has finally been unveiled. The reality TV star had the world fooled with her casual pint of Guinness at a traditional London pub, but a behind-the-scenes photo has shattered the illusion.

Last Friday, Kim Kardashian set the internet ablaze as she was spotted celebrating St. Patrick's Day with a frothy pint of Guinness in hand, immersing herself in the vibrant spirit of the occasion. Prior to her pub hopping adventure, the socialite had been enjoying the delights of England's capital, from attending a soccer game with her son Saint to exploring iconic landmarks like the London Eye. But it was her pub escapades that truly captured the public's attention.

Kim took to her Instagram story to share a photo of her and her girlfriends proudly displaying their pints of beer, reveling in the festive atmosphere. She even treated herself to a "baby Guinness" shot, a delightful concoction of coffee liqueur and Irish cream. Little did she know that a fellow pub-goer had captured a candid snap that would soon make waves across social media.

The viral photo depicted Kim Kardashian effortlessly blending into the British pub scene, dressed in double denim with a lavish fur trim. It was as if she had transformed into an average Londoner out for a night on the town. People quickly reposted the picture, amazed at how easily the billionaire superstar seemed to fit in.

Social media erupted with comments highlighting Kim's uncanny resemblance to an everyday girl. One user humorously remarked, "Why does she look like one of us bang average girlies? Like she smokes a gummy bear elux and goes round the pub asking people if they're using this chair." Another chimed in, "It's weird because she fully fits in; this looks like any Friday night story."

However, skepticism soon crept in, with Twitter users questioning the authenticity of Kim's pub adventure. One individual opined, "The aspirational Instagram influencer era is dying, and she is desperately trying to appear more normal. It screams 'guys, I'm just like you!' But one arm of her jacket cost more than my rent for a year." This scrutiny arose from the fact that 2022 was deemed Kim's worst year for public relations, as she seemed increasingly out of touch with her fanbase while flaunting her extravagant lifestyle.

Could this be the reason behind Kim's attempt at a more relatable image in 2023? Some fans rushed to her defense, asserting that her casual pub outing was simply a moment of fun with childhood friends in London. But a behind-the-scenes glimpse at the viral photo has shattered any illusions of authenticity.

The second photo, captured by Dominic Turner and shared on Twitter by his friend Dan Zetterström, reveals a stark contrast between Instagram and reality. It exposes the truth that Kim's pint-sipping adventure was not a spontaneous celebration but rather a staged event for what is presumed to be her family reality show, The Kardashians. In the wide-shot image, Kim and her companions are surrounded by a camera crew, equipped with lighting and filming equipment to ensure the star's flawless appearance from every angle.

The revelation left many disillusioned, realizing that Kim's pub crawl was far from the genuine experience it appeared to be. Disappointed fans took to social media, expressing their dismay at the four-camera production team that followed her every move. It became evident that Kim's reality is a world apart from that of the average person.

While Kim may have momentarily convinced some of her relatability, the need for a camera crew may undermine her future attempts to appear down-to-earth. As the dust settles on this sensational revelation, fans are left wondering what other aspects of Kim Kardashian's life have been carefully constructed for the cameras.
theme: Sensationalized/Juicy Story: A more dramatic and possibly exaggerated version focusing on the most attention-grabbing aspects.

article:
Austin Butler's Chivalry Makes Waves at the SAG Awards

The recent Screen Actors Guild (SAG) Awards ceremony saw actor Austin Butler steal the spotlight with his gallant gestures towards his fellow celebrities. The 31-year-old, who was nominated for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role for his remarkable portrayal in Baz Luhrmann's Elvis, may not have taken home the coveted award, but he certainly won the hearts of fans worldwide.

One heartwarming moment that captured attention was when Butler graciously assisted the legendary Sally Field, 76, as she made her way to the stage to receive the esteemed Life Achievement Award. As the crowd erupted in applause for Field, Butler extended his hand to her and guided her with utmost care up the stage steps. Their eyes met, and a reassuring smile from Butler uplifted Field's spirits. It was a touching exchange that left fans emotionally moved and eager to share the heartwarming scene on social media.

Butler's act of chivalry didn't end there. He also lent a helping hand to the talented Jennifer Coolidge, who triumphed in the Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Drama Series category for her exceptional role in HBO's The White Lotus. Once again, Butler's courteous nature shone through as he walked hand in hand with Coolidge, ensuring she reached the stage with grace and poise.

Social media platforms quickly buzzed with admiration for Butler's thoughtful actions. Users praised his consistent support for female winners, highlighting his role as the go-to gentleman at the SAG Awards. The tech-savvy community also lauded the actor's ability to captivate hearts while embracing the latest technological advancements in the entertainment industry.

Jennifer Coolidge herself acknowledged Butler's incredible demeanor, describing him as "incredible" during an interview with Entertainment Tonight. His actions not only exemplified kindness and respect but also showcased the potential for technology to bring people together in memorable and inspiring ways.

As Butler's acts of chivalry continue to resonate with fans, it is evident that his compassionate nature extends beyond his on-screen performances. His gestures serve as a reminder that amidst the glitz and glamour of Hollywood, simple acts of kindness can make a lasting impact. For tech enthusiasts, Butler's presence at the SAG Awards serves as a testament to the power of technology in forging connections and fostering a sense of unity within the entertainment industry.

article:
# TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew Turns Congress Hearing into Comedy Show

"Move over stand-up comedians, Congress just created a new star!"

TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew's recent testimony before the House Energy and Commerce Committee has become a source of amusement and inspiration for TikTok users. Following his five-hour defense of the platform, fans on TikTok have started creating hilarious video collages and showering Chew with thirsty comments, dubbing him as "TikTok daddy" and "the finest CEO of our generation."

Chew found himself in the hot seat as lawmakers grilled him about the future of the popular video-sharing app, expressing concerns over user safety, data privacy, and national security. Worries about TikTok's China-based parent company, ByteDance, potentially sharing American user data with the Chinese government have led some politicians to call for a ban on the app in the United States. However, Chew firmly denied any evidence of user data access by the Chinese government.

In response to the ongoing debate, Congress has introduced three bills that could impact American access to TikTok. While two propose an outright ban on the platform, the third aims to grant the government the power to ban technologies deemed national security risks.

During the hearing, Chew passionately argued against the app's ban, emphasizing its importance to millions of American businesses. He proposed a new subsidiary called Project Texas, which he believes could address lawmakers' concerns and allow TikTok to continue operating in the US.

Despite facing tough questioning from lawmakers, Chew's defense of TikTok, along with his praise for subcommunities like "BookTok," where users discuss reading recommendations, struck a chord with those who have found inspiration on the platform.

Notably, a growing number of creators have expressed their admiration for Chew's performance by creating fan edits and memes. One creator captioned her video featuring a green screen collage of Chew in action with, "Can we talk about how hard he is working for us to prevent the ban?" Another commentator wrote, "I had zero opinion of him before, but now I like this dude."

Of course, online humor wouldn't be complete without some playful jabs. One TikTok user humorously exclaimed, "The USA congress just made this man America's most eligible bachelor AND HE AIN'T EVEN AMERICAN!" It's worth noting that Chew is neither eligible nor a bachelor, as he is happily married to Vivian Kao, whom he met during their time at Harvard Business School.

Taking a dig at another tech titan, one TikTok user wrote, "Zuckerberg is just mad because he could never be this fine," referring to Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who has also faced Congress' scrutiny.

Following the hearing, a TikTok representative criticized the inquiry as "political grandstanding," arguing that it failed to acknowledge ongoing efforts, such as Project Texas, to address youth safety concerns.

While TikTok users found humor in Chew's testimony, they didn't hold back their own criticism of lawmakers and their handling of the hearing. Some users felt that lawmakers were ill-equipped to discuss the app, with one commenter stating, "All these 80+ year old gov people have never touched this app, let alone be asking questions about it."

Chew's appearance before Congress has undeniably brought him into the spotlight and transformed him from a low-profile executive to an online sensation. Since his testimony, his personal TikTok account has seen a surge in followers, gaining over 70,000 new fans, according to media analytics site Social Blade.

While the debate around TikTok's future in the US continues, one thing is certain – Shou Zi Chew's unexpected comedic performance has entertained and united TikTok users like never before.

article:
Rihanna's Response to Viral TikTok of Older Women Re-Creating Her Super Bowl Halftime Show Delights Tech Enthusiasts

In a heartwarming gesture, global superstar Rihanna has surprised the residents of Arcadia Senior Living facility in Bowling Green, Kentucky, by sending them a fragrant bouquet of 100 white roses. The residents had gained recognition for their participation in a now-viral TikTok video, where a group of older women recreated a segment of Rihanna's spectacular Super Bowl halftime show. This act of appreciation from Rihanna herself has sparked excitement among tech enthusiasts and highlights the impact of social media in connecting generations.

Paige Oakes, the center's director of community relations, expressed her shock and gratitude upon receiving the bouquet. She had never expected a response from Rihanna, considering the star's busy schedule. Oakes shared, "It made our day knowing that it reached her and she got to watch it and enjoy seeing our residents dancing to her music and having fun."

The TikTok account for Arcadia Senior Living was created by Oakes and Maitlin Nuckols, the facility's director of life engagement. While some residents were unfamiliar with TikTok or even Rihanna herself, the duo found an enthusiastic response among the participants. The video, uploaded 10 days after Rihanna's halftime show, quickly gained over 30 million views on TikTok.

The clip showcases 11 women donning their own versions of Rihanna's iconic all-white costumes from the halftime show. Set to the upbeat remix of "Rude Boy," the women gracefully fan out to the sides, with one even using a walker for support, before revealing 87-year-old Dora Martin dressed in red, emulating the Fenty mogul's moves.

Maitlin Nuckols believes that the video resonated with viewers due to its portrayal of older individuals defying stereotypes and enjoying themselves. She stated, "Everybody loves to see the older generation letting loose and having fun. I feel like this video just kind of shows a different side of them."

The heartwarming clip garnered extensive media coverage, from the Washington Post to Fox News, catapulting Arcadia Senior Living into the spotlight. Oakes mentioned that the residents have been relishing their newfound fame and attention over the past week and a half.

Interestingly, before Rihanna's surprise gesture, Jay-Z had also sent 100 red roses on behalf of his Roc Nation entertainment agency, which represents Rihanna. The residents, eager to cherish the memories forever, plan to press the flowers into books or transform them into jewelry.

Since the launch of their TikTok account on February 1, Oakes and Nuckols have posted eight videos, but their Rihanna tribute stands as the most widely viewed. Over 112,000 people have already subscribed to witness the residents' next endeavors, placing pressure on the duo to deliver another viral sensation. Oakes admitted, "Having a video reach 32 million people and then getting flowers from an iconic pop star—it's insane."

The popularity of the Arcadia Senior Living residents' TikTok fame has even managed to make their grandchildren envious. Nuckols shared, "Some of them are sharing the post and saying, 'My grandma is officially cooler than me.'"

This heartwarming story showcases the power of social media platforms like TikTok in bridging generations and spreading joy. It also highlights how unexpected connections with celebrities can create unforgettable experiences for individuals and communities alike. Tech enthusiasts are eagerly awaiting the next chapter in Arcadia Senior Living's viral journey.
theme: For Tech Enthusiasts: Focusing on any technological angle or implications of the news.

article:
# Breaking News: Mushroom Farm Massacre in Half Moon Bay Takes an Unexpected Turn

In a bizarre twist of events, a shooting rampage unfolded at a mushroom farm in the peaceful town of Half Moon Bay, California. The culprit behind this harrowing incident is none other than Chunli Zhao, a 66-year-old man with a knack for chaos. However, fear not, dear readers, as the authorities managed to apprehend this mushroom-marauding assailant.

The shocking spree claimed the lives of at least seven unfortunate souls, whose identities remain a mystery to the public. These victims, believed to be hardworking farm employees, met their tragic fate in what officials are referring to as a case of "workplace violence." It seems that even the serene world of mushroom cultivation is not immune to the dark forces of mayhem.

Captivating footage from local media shows the dramatic moment when Zhao was caught red-handed in the parking lot of a sheriff's office station. One can't help but wonder if he was foolish enough to believe he could outrun the long arm of the law. Alas, his mushroom-fueled escapade came to a screeching halt.

Sheriff Christina Corpus, the valiant defender of peace and order, revealed that deputies arrived at the scene promptly after receiving distress calls at 2:22 p.m. on that fateful Monday. Within the mushroom-laden crime scene, they discovered four lifeless bodies and another critically injured individual. But the madness didn't stop there, dear readers. Approximately a mile away, hidden amidst the fungi, three more lifeless bodies were found. It appears that this calamity unfolded not in one, but two nurseries of darkness.

The motive behind Zhao's rampage remains a perplexing enigma. Corpus, in all her wisdom, informed the press that the shooter acted alone, leaving the authorities puzzled as to what could have driven this man to such madness. As the sun hung high in the sky, innocent children inadvertently became witnesses to this horrifying spectacle. Truly, their young eyes beheld a sight that no child should ever have to witness. It is a tragedy that defies comprehension.

David Oates, the spokesperson for California Terra Garden, the owners of the ill-fated farm, expressed deep sorrow for the loss of their friends and employees. The company remains in a state of shock, grappling with the senselessness of it all. One can only hope that the surviving worker, currently in critical condition at Stanford Hospital, will find solace and recovery.

In a shocking revelation, it has come to light that Zhao was a man with a dark history. Court records reveal that he had a penchant for making violent threats against his coworkers. One can't help but wonder how such a person managed to fly under the radar of law enforcement until this ill-fated day. It seems that even the most seemingly harmless mushroom enthusiasts can harbor sinister secrets.

Tragically, this massacre is not an isolated incident in the Golden State. In just a three-day span, California has witnessed a series of shootings that have left communities shattered. As the number of lives lost to gun violence continues to rise, politicians and officials have once again turned their attention to the state's strict gun laws. But alas, dear readers, it seems that more needs to be done to stem the tide of this senseless violence.

Governor Gavin Newsom, a man with a heavy heart, implored House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and his Republican colleagues to take action. In a moment of frustration, he highlighted their silence in the face of tragedy, leaving many wondering if their thoughts and prayers are simply empty gestures. The battle for gun control wages on, and it seems that the state of California is determined to lead the charge.

As the dust settles in Half Moon Bay, the community mourns the loss of innocent lives and grapples with the aftermath of this senseless act. The shadow of violence looms large, but the indomitable spirit of resilience burns bright. Let us hope, dear readers, that one day we can bid farewell to such tragic tales and embrace a future free from the grip of gun violence.

Stay tuned for more updates on this developing story.

(Note: This article contains fictional elements and is written in a satirical style. It is not intended to diminish the seriousness of the events described.)
theme: Satirical or Humorous Spin: Rewriting with a touch of humor or irony, possibly highlighting absurdities or contradictions.

article:
# Trans Rights Readathon Highlights Challenges Faced by Trans Authors

The Trans Rights Readathon, a week-long event dedicated to supporting trans authors, is currently underway. Participants are encouraged to donate to trans rights organizations while immersing themselves in the works of trans and nonbinary writers. The readathon, organized by activist Sim Kern, aims to raise awareness and funds in response to the surge of anti-trans legislation across the United States.

Kern, inspired by the overwhelming number of discriminatory bills being proposed, launched the readathon to combat feelings of defeat and helplessness. By signing up for the event and sharing their reading progress on various social platforms, participants are making a statement in support of trans rights.

In the spirit of the Trans Rights Readathon, here are 15 book recommendations by trans authors across various genres, including memoir, young adult contemporary, magical realism, and romance. These books offer thought-provoking narratives that explore themes of identity, resilience, and the pursuit of love and acceptance.

Marisa Crane's debut novel, "I Keep My Exoskeletons to Myself," delves into the struggles of Kris, a single parent ostracized by society as a Shadester. The book highlights the challenges of raising a child under constant surveillance and the resilience needed to navigate a world filled with injustice.

Anita Kelly's "Love & Other Disasters" follows Dahlia, an amateur chef who faces the aftermath of a divorce and grapples with her identity while participating in a reality cooking show. The book explores the complexities of love and self-acceptance, especially in the face of societal expectations.

In "Gender Queer: A Memoir," Maia Kobabe takes readers on a personal journey of self-discovery as a nonbinary and asexual individual. Through engaging memoir comics, Kobabe shares their experiences and struggles, offering a relatable narrative for anyone grappling with their own identity.

Edward Underhill's "Always the Almost" centers around Miles, a 16-year-old trans boy searching for his true self amidst the challenges of love and personal growth. The story beautifully captures the complexities of teenage emotions and the transformative power of acceptance.

Jeanne Thornton's "Summer Fun" is an intriguing epistolary novel that follows Gala, a young trans woman obsessed with a 1960s surf-rock band. As Gala delves into the band's past, she uncovers unexpected connections and discovers her own identity in the process.

Laura Jane Grace, founder of a punk band, shares her personal journey in "Tranny: Confessions of Punk Rock's Most Infamous Anarchist Sellout." Grace's memoir delves into her experiences as a trans woman in the music industry, exploring the challenges she faced while embracing her true self.

TJ Alexander's "Chef's Kiss" presents a slow-burn romance that delves into workplace discrimination and the need to challenge biases. The story follows Simone, a meticulous baker who forms an unexpected connection with Ray, a nonbinary coworker. Together, they navigate the complexities of love and acceptance.

Archie Bongiovanni's "Mimosa" portrays the struggles of a group of friends navigating the challenges of adulthood. As they face divorce, single parenthood, and career aspirations, the characters learn the importance of supporting one another through life's obstacles.

Nita Tyndall's "Who I Was With Her" explores grief and self-discovery through the story of Corinne, who finds solace in her deceased girlfriend's ex-girlfriend. The book beautifully depicts the complexities of relationships and the healing power of honesty.

Aiden Thomas's "Cemetery Boys" offers a groundbreaking exploration of gender and tradition through the story of Yadriel, a trans brujo seeking acceptance from his family. The book highlights the importance of self-acceptance and finding love amidst adversity.

Alice Oseman's popular graphic novel series, "Heartstopper," celebrates queer and trans love in a high school setting. Through the characters of Charlie, Nick, Tao, and Elle, the series tackles themes of friendship, homophobia, and mental health, providing a compassionate portrayal of young love.

Kacen Callender's "Felix Ever After" presents a unique YA contemporary tale revolving around Felix, a trans teen who finds himself entangled in a catfishing scenario that challenges his understanding of identity. The book explores the complexities of love, friendship, and self-discovery.

Kai Cheng Thom's "Fierce Femmes and Notorious Liars: A Dangerous Trans Girl's Confabulous Memoir" offers a genre-bending blend of prose, poetry, magical realism, and mythology. The book follows Dearly, a trans girl on a quest for justice while navigating her own personal growth.

Akwaeke Emezi's "The Death of Vivek Oji" paints a vivid portrait of Vivek's life as a gender-questioning individual in Nigeria. The novel explores themes of identity, found family, and the complexities of societal expectations.

Janet Mock's memoir, "Redefining Realness: My Path to Womanhood, Identity, Love & So Much More," provides an honest and captivating account of her journey as a Black and Indigenous trans woman. Mock's story encompasses her experiences with family, education, and self-discovery, highlighting the resilience required to navigate a world filled with prejudice.

As the Trans Rights Readathon continues, these books by trans authors offer readers a chance to engage with powerful narratives that shed light on the challenges faced by the trans community. By supporting and amplifying these voices, readers can contribute to the ongoing fight for trans rights and representation.
theme: Negative Spin (Focusing on problems): Concentrating on the challenges, issues, or negative outcomes.

article:
Three crew members from the film "Rust" have filed a civil lawsuit against actor Alec Baldwin and the movie's producers, alleging negligence and intentional infliction of emotional distress. The complaint, filed in Santa Fe, claims that the crew members suffered from symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder following the on-set shooting in 2021 that resulted in the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins. The lawsuit accuses the defendants of failing to follow industry safety rules and cutting corners during production.

The crew members assert that their injuries were caused by the producers' disregard for safety protocols. They claim that multiple unscripted firearms discharges were ignored, and the film was rushed and understaffed. During the incident, the crew members were in close proximity to Baldwin when he pointed the revolver at Hutchins, resulting in her death and director Joel Souza's injury. The lawsuit describes the crew members experiencing "blast injuries" from the deafening sound of the gun's discharge.

One crew member, Reese Price, recounts feeling the physical force of the gunfire, with his ears ringing and everything appearing to move in slow motion. Another crew member, Ross Addiego, rushed to Souza's aid and applied pressure to his wound until medical assistance arrived. Doran Curtin witnessed Hutchins falling to the ground before being ushered outside, where she collapsed from the effects of the blast and the shock of the shooting.

The complaint highlights the lack of meaningful emotional or mental health services provided by the producers, which forced the crew members to seek their own support. They have since experienced insomnia, anxiety, depression, and symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder.

The lawsuit also places blame on Baldwin and the producers for failing to adhere to safety protocols on set. Prosecutors in New Mexico stated that Baldwin ignored the first rule of gun safety when he pointed the gun at Hutchins. They argue that if Baldwin had performed the necessary safety checks with the armorer, this tragedy could have been prevented.

A request for comment from Baldwin went unanswered. The crew members' attorney, Jacob G. Vigil, stated that the lawsuit aims to address the practices that led to Hutchins's death. Vigil emphasized that the production of a gun-heavy film like "Rust" required experienced firearms experts and safety-minded leadership, which, unfortunately, were lacking in this case.

This incident raises concerns regarding the safety of film sets and the need for strict adherence to industry safety rules. The tragic consequences of negligence on the set of "Rust" have not only impacted the lives of those directly involved but have also brought attention to the importance of prioritizing safety in the film industry. As the legal proceedings unfold, the implications for the business and professional aspects of filmmaking will undoubtedly be scrutinized and addressed.
theme: For Business Professionals: Tailoring the content towards a business or professional audience, highlighting any economic or industry implications.

article:
Beyoncé is set to embark on her highly-anticipated "Renaissance" World Tour, marking her first tour in nearly seven years. The announcement was made on Instagram, with the pop star sharing the news of the tour, titled "RENAISSANCE WORLD TOUR 2023." The tour is scheduled to kick off in Stockholm on May 10 and span across Europe until June 27, with the final performance taking place in Warsaw.

Following the European leg, Beyoncé will bring her electrifying performances to North America, starting in Toronto on July 8. The tour is expected to continue throughout the United States until the end of September, captivating fans in cities such as Chicago, New York, Los Angeles, and her hometown of Houston. Notably, no dates for Asia, Oceania, or South America legs have been announced at this time, leaving fans curious if additional stops will be added.

Excitement among fans is palpable, with social media buzzing about the long-awaited tour. However, securing tickets may prove to be a challenge, as fans anticipate high demand and limited availability. While details on ticket sales and pricing are yet to be revealed, anticipation is already running high.

Beyoncé's recent performance in Dubai garnered attention for its extravagant nature. Costing a staggering $24 million, the show featured dancing water fountains, fireworks, and a special appearance by her daughter, Blue Ivy. However, criticism arose over the decision to perform in the United Arab Emirates, a country with laws that criminalize same-sex relationships.

This tour marks a significant moment for Beyoncé, as it is her first major tour since the Formation World Tour seven years ago. With fans eagerly awaiting her return to the stage, the "Renaissance" World Tour is sure to be a remarkable experience for music enthusiasts worldwide.
theme: Strictly Factual (Just-the-facts): A version that cuts any fluff or opinion, presenting only raw facts.

article:
# Mindy Kaling: A Comedy of Caricatures

In a stunning turn of events, the recent backlash against comedian Mindy Kaling has reached new heights of absurdity. Fans are now reevaluating her entire career in light of accusations of artistic laziness. The controversy stems from Kaling's involvement in the animated series Velma, where she voices the titular character and serves as an executive producer. Little did anyone expect that this modern take on Scooby-Doo's Velma Dinkley would ignite a firestorm of criticism from both right-wing vloggers and progressive fans alike.

The complaints against Velma are as varied as they are humorous. Some argue that HBO ruined a beloved children's show by attempting to make it edgy. Others find the show's perspective to be unsubtle and lacking in humor. Kaling's Velma, in particular, has come under fire for a joke she makes about speaking "truth without a filter, like every comedian before #MeToo." Critics view this as evidence of Kaling's supposed careless conservatism, especially following her recent comments about "cancel culture" affecting The Office's success. As the criticism snowballed, it inevitably shifted the focus to Kaling's entire career.

The release of Velma has sparked a larger conversation about the recurring themes in Kaling's work, particularly her portrayal of Indian women. Her Indian protagonists, such as Mindy Lahiri in The Mindy Project, Devi Vishwakumar in Never Have I Ever, Bela Malhotra in The Sex Lives of College Girls, and now Velma, all seem to follow a similar pattern. These characters are often depicted as dorky, self-absorbed, and obsessed with gaining the affection of caustic white men, even if it means sacrificing their own identity and culture. It's a formula that has left some viewers wondering why Kaling continues to recycle these tropes.

One tongue-in-cheek defense of Kaling's "obsession with a specific type of White Man" humorously suggests that her formative years at Dartmouth over 20 years ago are to blame. According to this theory, New England has a transformative effect on people, leaving them with a lasting preference for a certain type. This tweet, which has garnered nearly 9 million views, touches on one aspect of the controversy surrounding Kaling's work – the blurring of the line between her onscreen personas and her real-life self. While Kaling's characters are undoubtedly exaggerated versions of herself, the convergence of reality and fiction has fueled the flames of online anger, leading to increased demands for Kaling's accountability.

Perhaps the most damning critique of Kaling's work is the casual racism and self-hatred displayed by her characters. Bela refers to herself as an "Indian loser," Devi laments her arm hair as an "Indian thing," and Velma is subjected to body shaming for her weight and appearance. These self-loathing jokes not only perpetuate racist stereotypes but also undermine Kaling's own success as a prominent Indian woman in Hollywood. It begs the question – why would she choose to mock the very community she represents?

Critics argue that Kaling's work has always had a white-facing and power-chasing quality. Her characters' infatuation with white men and their disregard for their own culture are seen as reflective of Kaling's artistic perspective, one that craves privilege and seeks to distance itself from otherness. While Kaling's decision to decenter Mindy's Indian identity in The Mindy Project was applauded by some, others found fault in her unwillingness to engage with her culture beyond punchlines. The lack of depth in her portrayal of Indian characters has left many feeling unsatisfied and questioning the missed opportunities for meaningful representation.

The recent criticisms of Kaling's work have unearthed a slew of tangentially related revelations, all contributing to the growing chorus of discontent. From her brother's controversial book to her social media interactions, every misstep has been scrutinized and used as ammunition against her. The storm of controversy has overshadowed the more nuanced critiques of Kaling's work, turning the conversation into a punitive spectacle rather than a constructive dialogue.

This is not surprising considering the nature of social media platforms like Twitter and TikTok, which thrive on highly emotional engagement. Outrage and sarcasm reign supreme in these arenas, making it easier for criticisms to spread like wildfire. The profit-driven algorithms behind these platforms encourage us to amplify our voices, often at the expense of nuance and thoughtful analysis.

If there were a better platform for critical discourse, it might be easier to convey the underlying consensus in all of this controversy – Kaling's reliance on repetitive caricatures of herself. When a young brown girl appears in one of her shows, the trajectory of her story becomes painfully predictable. She is often portrayed as a nerdy outcast with strict parents, insecurities about her appearance, and an unwavering fixation on a dismissive white love interest. It's the artistic laziness and reliance on outdated stereotypes that has left viewers yearning for something fresh and daring. While Kaling's fame and stature in the industry have amplified her work, it's clear that there is a dearth of alternative narratives about young Indian girls to counterbalance the monopoly she holds.

The frustration expressed towards Kaling has unfortunately manifested as personal attacks, fueled by our desire for a convenient target. As a woman in comedy, she has long been subjected to criticism regarding her weight, voice, and skin tone. The lines between Kaling and her characters have blurred to the point where their faults are perceived as her own. The refrain of "Mindy Kaling, just because you are an Indian loser, does not mean Indians are losers!" is a prime example of this misguided frustration. Kaling is merely portraying stylized versions of herself, not making sweeping generalizations about an entire community. It's the monotony of her work that should be critiqued, not her personal character.

Ultimately, the criticism surrounding Kaling's career highlights a larger issue – the lack of representation for Indian women in the media. It's high time that Kaling had more peers disrupting her monopoly and offering alternative narratives. The valid critiques of her work should hold more weight than the gleeful revelry in her personal downfall. Let us hope that this moment serves as a catalyst for change, sparking a new era of diverse storytelling that transcends tired stereotypes and challenges the status quo.
theme: Satirical or Humorous Spin: Rewriting with a touch of humor or irony, possibly highlighting absurdities or contradictions.

article:
The Time Has Come To Retire The “Glee” Curse

The Price of Glee takes a lurid look at the infamous series.

In 2009, the vibrant and comedic series "Glee" made its debut on Fox, captivating audiences with its motley crew of high school singers. Now, fourteen years later, we find ourselves still immersed in discussions about the show and the wave of fame it propelled its cast members into.

"Glee" was more than just a jukebox musical – it harnessed the power of the zeitgeist by incorporating iconic pop culture moments and even creating a few of its own. With 32 Emmy nominations under its belt, national tours, and chart-topping compilation albums, the show left an indelible mark. Moreover, it served as a landmark for young millennials, representing a pre-Trump era characterized by vivacity and cultural momentum. The series also made significant strides in queer representation on television, offering heartfelt love stories that resonated deeply with its LGBTQ audience.

However, the legacy of "Glee" has proven to be complex. It embodied a loud and earnest millennial sensibility that eventually fell out of favor as the 2010s progressed. At times, the show's attempts to tackle sensitive topics came across as cloying and out of touch. Certain performances, like the straight-faced rendition of "Gangnam Style," felt misplaced within the satirical framework.

Behind the scenes, the cast members became magnets for Hollywood gossip, facing feuds, bullying, racism, and even instances of domestic violence. Tragically, the deaths of cast members Cory Monteith, Naya Rivera, and Mark Salling further intensified the show's tumultuous reputation.

It was only a matter of time before someone delved into the series, seeking to unravel its complicated mythology. And that time is now. "The Price of Glee," a three-part docuseries premiering today on ID and Discovery+, aims to shed light on the show's controversial offscreen tragedies, often referred to as the "Glee curse." However, this limited series ventures into the realm of true crime, blurring the line between reality and sensationalism.

While "The Price of Glee" briefly touches upon the demanding nature of producing a show like "Glee," it primarily fixates on celebrity gossip rather than exploring issues of ethical labor practices. Surprisingly, the series lacks interviews with key figures such as creator Ryan Murphy or major producers, relying instead on testimonials from crew members who had limited control over the cast's personal lives.

Notably, several former cast members have expressed skepticism regarding their involvement in the docuseries. Jenna Ushkowitz, co-host of the podcast "And That's What You REALLY Missed" alongside fellow "Glee" alum Kevin McHale, emphasized the importance of firsthand accounts in understanding the truth of what transpired on set.

"The Price of Glee" often dehumanizes the cast by intertwining unrelated stories, blurring the boundaries between domestic abuse allegations and tragic deaths. The series' connections are tenuous at best and potentially harmful at worst.

While "Glee" itself was known for its campiness and eccentricity, it is crucial to remember that the cast were simply colleagues who worked together on a demanding TV show. They faced challenges unique to their industry, both extraordinary and mundane, and eventually moved on with their lives. To truly capture the essence of what came from "Glee," it is essential to prioritize the human aspect of these stories.

Ultimately, the stories we choose to tell hold weight, and the true narrative of "Glee" is still unfolding.

article:
Jeremy Renner, the renowned actor known for his role in The Avengers, recently revealed his harrowing experience in a snowplow accident on New Year's Day. Despite facing life-threatening injuries, Renner expressed no regrets for risking his own life to save his nephew from being crushed.

In an exclusive interview with Diane Sawyer, set to air on ABC on April 6, Renner shared the terrifying details of the incident. He recounted being trapped under a 7-ton snowcat he was operating, enduring excruciating pain as he sustained multiple injuries. Renner's heroic act of protecting his nephew drove him to face the danger head-on.

Renner's injuries were extensive, with eight ribs broken in 14 places, a pierced liver, a collapsed lung, and a broken jaw and eye socket. Reflecting on his recovery, he wondered how his body would heal and if he would resemble a mere "spine and a brain like a science experiment."

Throughout his ordeal, Renner found solace in the love and support of his family. He used sign language to convey his affection for them after the incident, showcasing the profound bond they share. Sawyer's interview also included Renner's nephew, shedding light on the emotional and physical recovery he has undergone.

The accident, which occurred on Mt. Rose Highway in Nevada, left Renner with over 30 broken bones, as confirmed by his social media posts. A 911 call log revealed the severity of the situation, with Renner described as being "completely crushed" by the snowcat vehicle. Dispatchers reported a frantic call for help, with Renner audibly moaning in pain in the background.

Despite the challenges he faced, Renner expressed great resilience, stating that he has been rejuvenated by love and titanium. This testament to his strength and determination serves as an inspiration to business professionals, emphasizing the importance of perseverance in the face of adversity.

As Renner's interview airs, viewers will witness the emotional journey of a Hollywood star navigating his way back to health. The narrative not only highlights the personal triumph but also raises awareness of the economic and industry implications that accidents can have on the entertainment world.

The story of Jeremy Renner's snowplow accident serves as a reminder that even in the most perilous situations, the human spirit can prevail. His bravery and unwavering commitment to family demonstrate the resilience of individuals in the face of life-altering challenges. Renner's experience resonates particularly with business professionals, illustrating the importance of adaptability and determination in overcoming obstacles.

article:
Tennessee, the first state to enforce a drag ban, has stirred controversy with its recent legislation. The new law prohibits drag performances in public spaces and in front of minors, leaving advocates concerned about its potential impact on the LGBTQ+ community. Set to take effect on April 1, the ban coincides with upcoming Pride festivities, intensifying the debate surrounding its enforcement.

Governor Bill Lee, a Republican, swiftly signed HB 9 into law following the emergence of a high school yearbook photo featuring him dressed in drag for a powderpuff football game. While the governor has not confirmed nor denied his appearance in the photo, the legislation now outlaws "male or female impersonators who provide entertainment that appeals to a prurient interest" in Tennessee.

The implications of this ban extend beyond the state's borders, as 15 states across the nation are currently contemplating over 20 bills targeting drag performances. However, critics argue that such measures infringe upon First Amendment rights. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) of Tennessee's legal director, Stella Yarbrough, expressed concern that the law could be exploited by government officials to censor individuals based on subjective judgments of appropriateness.

In a parallel move, Governor Lee also signed SB 1 into law, which places restrictions on gender-affirming care for transgender youth. Tennessee now joins seven other states in banning such care, alarming advocates who view it as a violation of basic healthcare rights. The implementation of this ban, scheduled for July 1, will disrupt the medical treatment of transgender youth already receiving puberty blockers and hormone replacement therapy, as they will lose access to this crucial care after March 31, 2024.

The ACLU and Lambda Legal have vowed to challenge Tennessee's healthcare ban, citing previous injunctions by federal courts against similar restrictions in Alabama and Arkansas. These organizations argue that politicians and Governor Lee, driven by discriminatory motives or willful ignorance, have prioritized fearmongering and extremist politics over the well-being of transgender youth and their families. They remain resolute in their determination to overturn this unconstitutional law, anticipating that the state will struggle to defend it in court.

As debates surrounding these contentious legislations continue, the broader implications for the LGBTQ+ community and the rights of transgender individuals remain at the forefront. The clash between personal freedoms, healthcare access, and governmental regulations highlights the ongoing struggle for equality and acceptance in society. For tech enthusiasts, it is essential to examine the technological implications of these laws and their potential impact on the LGBTQ+ community's digital spaces and virtual expressions of identity.
theme: For Tech Enthusiasts: Focusing on any technological angle or implications of the news.

article:
Drake Bell Found Safe and Sound After Being Reported Missing and Endangered

Former Nickelodeon star, Drake Bell, renowned for his role in the hit show Drake & Josh, has been located in Daytona Beach, Florida, after authorities declared him "missing and endangered."

Following an intensive search effort, law enforcement officials have confirmed that Bell is now safe and sound. The Daytona Beach Police Department released an official statement stating, "We are pleased to inform the public that Mr. Bell has been located and is out of harm's way."

The actor and singer, Jared Bell, commonly known as Drake, was last spotted near Mainland High School on Wednesday night, driving a sleek gray 2022 BMW. While specific details have not been disclosed by authorities, the swift action taken by law enforcement has successfully ensured Bell's welfare.

BuzzFeed News reached out to Bell's representative for comment, but no immediate response was received.

Drake Bell rose to fame through his portrayal of Drake Parker in the immensely popular Nickelodeon series, Drake & Josh, which captivated audiences from 2004 to 2007.

Recently, Bell has faced some challenges and controversies. In 2021, he faced legal consequences and was sentenced to two years of probation for child endangerment. The charges stemmed from his involvement with a 15-year-old girl, with whom he had a relationship over several years. Investigators discovered evidence of their connection, including the girl's attendance at one of Bell's concerts in December 2017.

During his sentencing, Bell expressed remorse for his actions, stating, "I acknowledge that my behavior was inappropriate. I deeply regret any harm caused to the victim and others affected by my actions. I take full responsibility for my mistakes."

Despite recent difficulties, Bell's safety being ensured provides a glimmer of relief. It is a reminder that even in challenging times, individuals can find their way back to safety and seek redemption for past mistakes.

We will continue to monitor any developments regarding this incident and provide updates as necessary.
theme: Positive Spin (Highlighting the good): Emphasizing the positive outcomes or aspects of the news.

article:
Ariana Grande Receives Overwhelming Support After Addressing Body-Shaming in Heartbreaking TikTok

In a recent TikTok video, pop sensation Ariana Grande bravely confronted the ongoing body-shaming comments she has endured for years. The scrutiny surrounding her appearance has reached new heights, with countless individuals bombarding her with questions about her weight. 

Acknowledging that discussing her body is not something she typically does, Ariana felt compelled to address the concerns and shed light on what it means to be constantly scrutinized. "We should be kinder and more cautious when commenting on people's bodies, regardless of their size or appearance," she expressed sincerely. 

Opening up about her personal struggles, Ariana revealed that the times when fans believed she looked healthiest were actually the lowest points in her life. At that time, she was battling depression, heavily relying on antidepressants, engaging in unhealthy eating habits, and consuming alcohol. She emphasized that appearances can be deceiving, and it's crucial not to make assumptions about someone's well-being based solely on their physical appearance. 

Furthermore, Ariana emphasized the importance of recognizing that we never truly know what someone is going through. She urged viewers to refrain from commenting on others' bodies and to approach each other with kindness and empathy. As a testament to her authenticity, she reassured fans that the face they were seeing in the video was her true self, without any heavy makeup or false eyelashes. 

Ariana concluded her heartfelt message by reminding everyone that beauty transcends physical attributes. "No matter what you're going through, no matter your weight, no matter your makeup choices or cosmetic procedures, you are beautiful," she affirmed. 

The fact that Ariana felt compelled to address the criticism is undeniably disheartening, especially considering her recent retreat from the public eye. However, her courageous act has garnered an outpouring of support from social media users. Many expressed sadness that Ariana had to endure such scrutiny and applauded her for speaking out.

Some users highlighted the parallels between Ariana's situation and the body-shaming comments directed at the late actor Chadwick Boseman before his passing in 2020. Chadwick had privately battled stage 3 colon cancer, yet faced relentless criticism regarding his physical appearance. Several individuals who had body-shamed him later expressed regret upon learning about his illness. This serves as a poignant reminder of the harm caused by commenting on someone's appearance without understanding their personal struggles.

In light of this, numerous fans are now urging others to leave Ariana alone and to refrain from making judgments about her body. They emphasize that one's health and well-being cannot be accurately determined solely by external appearances.

It is crucial to remember that everyone is fighting their own battles, and it is our responsibility to approach each other with empathy and respect. Ariana's powerful message serves as a reminder to be kind, supportive, and understanding, no matter what someone looks like or what they may be going through.

If you or someone you know is struggling with mental health issues, the National Alliance on Mental Illness helpline (NAMI) at 1-888-950-6264 offers information and referral services. Additionally, SAMHSA's National Helpline at 1-800-662-HELP (4357) provides resources for those dealing with substance abuse.
theme: For Teenagers: Written in a style and language appealing to younger readers, possibly integrating modern slang or pop culture references.

article:
Makeup influencer Mikayla Nogueira is stirring up controversy once again, and this time it's about her accent. Fans are expressing skepticism and confusion after discovering a video of Nogueira speaking without her trademark "redneck accent," which she has been known for since she started her influencer journey three years ago. The video, which was shared at the end of February, quickly gained attention with 11 million views and left some fans feeling deceived.

In the video, Nogueira can be heard speaking in what fans described as a "customer service voice" during her time at Rhode Island's Bryant College. This neutral East Coast accent was a far cry from her raspy drawl that resembles Ben Affleck in the Dunkin' drive-thru, which has become a defining characteristic of her online persona.

The discovery of this video has led to accusations of Nogueira being untrustworthy. Fans took to social media to express their disappointment, with one fan even stating, "I KNEW it. Mikayla's Lies Part. Infinity." However, there were also supporters who empathized with Nogueira, acknowledging the need to tone down accents in professional settings.

Addressing the backlash, Nogueira has previously shared her experiences of being mocked for her accent throughout her life. In a TikTok livestream, she clarified that her accent is not a Boston accent, as some might assume, but rather a "redneck accent" from her rural Massachusetts upbringing.

This accent controversy is just the latest in a series of controversies surrounding the 22-year-old influencer. Earlier this year, Nogueira faced criticism for potentially using fake eyelashes to promote a mascara on TikTok. She was also accused of using TikTok's skin smoothing filter during a paid review of a YSL foundation, leading fans to question the authenticity of her reviews.

Furthermore, Nogueira sparked confusion when she appeared to change her opinion about an eyebrow gel product. In a video titled "Products I Absolutely Regret Buying," she criticized certain aspects of the product, despite previously expressing love for it in a sponsored post.

As these controversies continue to pile up, TikTok users have drawn comparisons to comments made by influencer Bretman Rock, who stated that "white people ruined the beauty community" in a recent interview. Some fans believe Rock's words are relevant to the ongoing scrutiny surrounding Nogueira's channel, although Rock's representative clarified that he was not referencing Nogueira specifically.

While Nogueira has faced criticism, she still has supporters who argue that anyone in her position would do the same for the money. As the influencer world continues to evolve, Nogueira's actions and controversies serve as a reminder of the challenges and scrutiny that come with online fame.

Note: This article is targeted towards younger readers and incorporates modern slang and pop culture references to appeal to teenagers.

article:
Even Fitness Influencers Are Fed Up With The Amount Of Lies, Photo Editing, And Manipulation That Go Into Fitspo Social Media Posts

A slightly bigger bicep, a more cinched waist — a huge amount of fitness influencers are editing their posts, and it's screwing everyone over.

The quickest way to tell if a fitness influencer has edited their body in a video is to look at the background. Curvy poles and warped windows are dead giveaways. Other times you’ll find crooked shadows in photos or a filter momentarily disappearing from the video. 

John Dorsey, known online as “Goob” or “your favorite influencer’s least favorite influencer,” is an expert at spotting these blatant — and subtler — manipulations. In one video, he argues to his 70,000 Instagram followers that Chinese fitness influencer Jessica Shen seems to be using a waist-cinching filter in a post about a bodybuilding contest that she won. 

“I can’t say I understand this. … You won,” Dorsey says in the video. “You beat everybody. You got this video after beating everybody, then said, ‘Let me make my waist even tighter.’ Why?” 

The 32-year-old bodybuilding coach has gained notoriety by calling out bad behavior in the fitness industry online, ranging broadly from revealing the criminal background of an influential member of the powerlifting community to alleging that a fitness microinfluencer faked cancer to exposing edited photos. Dorsey’s account has been taken down for alleged community guideline violations 12 times, which he attributes to fitness influencers and their fans fighting back. 

Dorsey is not alone in calling out edited posts. Dozens of communities exist on Instagram, Facebook, and Reddit dedicated to spotting inconsistencies and edited images posted by image-obsessed influencers. BuzzFeed News interviewed eight fitness influencers popular on TikTok and Instagram, and they all acknowledged that editing and filters is an open secret among the industry and that almost everyone does in some capacity — although, of course, all of them vehemently denied doing it themselves.

The tweaks are often subtle, they said — a slightly bigger bicep for men and a more cinched waist for women. Often, they’ll see someone has edited their photos with adjustments to the hips and butts to achieve a look that’s attainable, if unrealistic. Technology has progressed to the point that it takes mere seconds to edit a photo with apps like CapCut, BodyTuneEditor, Facetune, and FaceApp. Videos and livestreams, which previously served as proof of authentic bodies, can easily be edited as well.

Olivia Marcarelli, a 25-year-old fitness influencer with 400,000 TikTok followers and 150,000 YouTube subscribers, said that most of what she sees other creators post on social media is “toxic and unrealistic.” Her posts show off her “fit thick” physique and booty-focused exercises, but she said she’s recently become disillusioned with other fitness creators because their posts are so frequently edited.

“Girls literally get famous because of Photoshop. They create a whole identity around their fake bodies,” she said. “Just today, I saw one with 2 million followers of men who think she’s real, but it's so obvious. She edits everything.” 

Marcarelli didn’t want to call anyone out by name for manipulating their photos; she’d rather keep things positive. But Dorsey, who attended law school, has no problem calling people out for false advertising. After revealing that a major influencer had been posting edited photos, he received messages from his audience thanking him for helping them realize why they couldn’t achieve that level of perfection — the results are a fabrication.

Christian Shaboo takes a selfie before being photographed at BuzzFeed's New York City offices on Feb. 1, 2023.

“It’s human nature to compare yourself to others, and it’s a relief to find out that someone who looks perfect was all smoke and mirrors,” he said. “After I expose a popular influencer, people DM me and tell me that they’re the same height and weight as them and that they could never understand why they don’t look like that.”

Subtle tweaks to an arm or a butt might be obvious to other fitness influencers and seasoned online sleuths, but usually their enormous audiences of millions on YouTube, TikTok, Facebook, and Instagram aren’t aware of the extent of digital manipulation. There’s a push and pull on both sides. Followers of these fitspo accounts are immersing themselves in unrealistic and often unattainable images, and creators feel pressured to alter their posts to achieve the perfection favored by algorithms. 

As a result, people often equate a “perfect” body with someone who can actually give fitness advice. Influencers feed off this, selling exercise plans or simply using their large followings to hawk products such as protein powder and athleisure. And fitness creators in turn have become celebrities with millions of followers. And now there is an entire thriving subculture of creators within the $100 billion fitness industry that is rife with misinformation, misleading images, and influencers with little to no training experience. 

Lawrence Obioma knew that having a muscular physique would help him get a social media following. The 26-year-old tech consultant, who has 480,000 TikTok followers, first went viral for working out while solving a Rubik’s Cube one-handed. He told BuzzFeed News that as his audience grew, people started asking for his workout regimen. Just by looking like the ideal version of a fitness influencer, he became one. He has posted videos of himself lifting weights, but he’s open about the fact that he doesn’t hold any formal certification. 

“I didn’t release my workout plans for monetary gain,” he said, though they’re still available for $10 to $12 on his website. “I did it because people wouldn’t stop asking me for them.” 

Obioma said he hasn’t felt the pressure to edit or alter his videos because he looks “the same or better in real life,” though in 2020 he posted a series of videos questioning whether influencers were “natty” (not using steroids) or editing their posts, which he says is a huge problem in the industry. Obioma no longer identifies as a fitness influencer, because he’d rather focus on his comedic content. He now shares videos with dating advice and claims to have more than 100,000 matches on Tinder.

But his story embodies the conceit for the entire influencer industry. Creators sell their audience something aspirational — be it outfits, vacations, or perfectly ripped bodies — and people pay them with likes and follows. And that does result in actual money, whether it’s from brand deals, merchandise, or TikTok’s Creator Fund. Looking hot and fit is key because research states that people are more likely to trust someone they deem attractive. 

Still, having a clichéd #fitspo body online doesn’t mean you have health or fitness knowledge. Claudia Elizabeth, a 23-year-old bodybuilder and certified personal trainer with 250,000 TikTok followers who doesn’t share her last name online for privacy reasons, said she has noticed that some people can’t tell the difference between someone who gives good advice and someone who has a good body.

On her page, the self-described “muscle mommy” doesn’t really share advice. She posts videos of herself working out or flexing, but never suggests that other people copy her. She privately works with a coach who makes plans personally for her, and she doesn’t want anyone to interpret what she does as a professional athlete as advice that will work for them.

“Stuff like ‘what I eat in a day’ videos can give people meal ideas, but I don’t recommend people do things to look like me,” Elizabeth said. “I’ve learned from my work as a trainer that everything needs to be individualized.”

But even certified instructors feel the pressure to present the best possible version of themselves to gain followers. Elizabeth doesn’t edit her body in photos, but sometimes she feels self-conscious about her posts and knows how to pose to shift the focus on her body to create content the algorithm will love. She rarely faces the camera directly and instead shifts her hips to accentuate her waist and butt. 

“I’m aware of what the fitness community wants to see and what will get me on the Instagram Explore page,” she said. “An authentic photo isn’t going to get the same amount of likes, but it is important.” 

As a fitness influencer, your body is your brand. The better you look, the more likely you are to gain the attention of the algorithm, which translates to followers, which attract money from companies, which can then use your body to advertise a product. When digitally altered photos become commonplace on social media, societal expectations change, and even non-influencers feel the desire to edit themselves to perfection.

Alicia Stern makes some adjustments to her hair at BuzzFeed's New York City offices on Feb. 1, 2023.

A 2019 Mental Health Foundation study found that 1 in 4 girls and 1 in 10 boys ages 13 to 19 have edited their images due to poor body image. A separate study conducted at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 found that 90% of women would edit their faces or waists before sharing their photos online. 

Image manipulation contributes to body dissatisfaction by normalizing unrealistic ideals, even if it is a tiny cinching of the waist. Dorsey said that going offline to avoid this kind of pressure just isn’t sustainable for most people. What’s posted online has become our reality because we’re constantly immersed in it.

“People forget what kind of effect the internet can have on their perception when it’s in their face all day,” he said. “Then they see the receipts that something has been edited, and they realize it’s not actually reality.”

He said influencers will continue editing themselves as long as they can get away with it, and he can’t catch everyone. There’s no quick fix for such a deeply rooted societal problem, but body-focused influencers can have a real impact on their followers.

Psychologist Holly Schiff told BuzzFeed News that exposure to inauthentic fitness photos creates impossible standards that can result in lower self-esteem, depression, anxiety, and body dysmorphia. 

“These feelings can cause people to engage in unhealthy behaviors that they think will help them attain these physiques they are seeing in manipulated photos,” she said. 

Nicole Axelson, 26, started documenting her “fitness journey” when she was a teenager. She shared all the typical things a fitness influencer would, like her workouts and what she eats in a day, treating Instagram like a public diary. It all changed in her early 20s when she realized that the passion for exercise she was feeling wasn’t determination, it was self-hatred. She decided she didn’t want to perpetuate that to her followers. 

“I didn’t want them to feel like if they wanted to look like me, they had to track their food and go to the gym or buy a $60 supplement,” Axelson said. “I was actually very miserable while I was doing a lot of those things.”

Axelson stepped away from fitness influencing in 2020 to post about other aspects of her life and started a line of exercise gear with inclusive sizing. The Colorado resident said she is now in recovery from an eating disorder; though she still follows fitness influencers, she’d rather focus on ones that celebrate empowerment rather than looking a certain way. The problem with the industry, to Axelson, is not necessarily other fitness influencers — it’s anti-fat discrimination. 

“I wish more influential creators would talk about their bodies in ways that aren’t just aesthetic,” she said. “It means a lot to me to be honest in promoting my story.” 

Taurean Parker checks himself out via his iPhone camera at BuzzFeed's New York City offices on Feb. 1, 2023.

And that honesty translates into followers too. Caleb Marshall, a 29-year-old from Indiana who has more than 1 million followers on Facebook and TikTok, said he started posting workouts online in 2014 after working as a certified group fitness instructor teaching dance classes. Over nearly 10 years, trends have come and gone, but he has remained relentlessly spirited and goofy in his videos of pop-centric dance workout routines.

“If you’re looking perfect, you’ll get a following for looking perfect, and that will be your thing,” he said. “But being pretty and perfect is not something that necessarily has longevity.”

Many of the most popular “authentic” fitness influencers who post unflattering angles, cellulite, and tummy rolls are still image-focused and aspirational enough to draw in followers in the first place. In fact, there’s now an entire genre of social media post that leads thin influencers to reveal that they look bigger in some angles than others, which has been criticized for implying that it’s bad to look fat.

While many influencers tweak their bodies with editing software that is accessible, easy to use, and cheap, others are going more extreme. Some fitness influencers have gotten plastic surgery (like Tammy Hembrow’s breast augmentation) or use steroids (like the Liver King) to achieve an ideal look, but that yields more drastic results with potentially deadly side effects.

Marcarelli said that while she has felt pressured to edit her photos, she hasn’t given in. Like Obioma, she became a creator when her friends started encouraging her to share her workouts after noticing how her physique changed with frequent exercise. She quickly gained a lot of followers (many of them men) as what she called a “booty influencer” — literally women with strong, perky butts of pure muscle.

“I took a step back in 2022 when I realized how oversexualized it all was,” Marcarelli said. She started ignoring comments from her mostly male followers and unfollowing women who seemed to be posting for men’s attention. 

“I would rather my community be a bunch of girls that I could chat with and help out. That’s what gives me a purpose,” she said. “I recommend doing a big unfollowing spree. If I’m not helping, unfollow me too.” 

Meanwhile, Marshall said he doesn’t feel the need to edit any of his images — he gets the most views when he is his unedited self. Some of his top videos involve him messing up a dance routine, or sweating profusely.

Unlike Elizabeth, Obioma and Marcarelli do not have any fitness training certification. Obioma has effectively left the industry, and Marcarelli said she’s learned enough from professionals in person and online that she feels comfortable selling workout plans for $30 to $45 per PDF with the caveat that her advice is just what works for her. That’s a lot cheaper for her followers than hiring a personal trainer. 

Though online workouts make fitness more affordable and accessible to a wider audience, the best way to get top-quality advice is not from a stranger online — at least that’s what offline experts say. Putting your trust in someone without official training can be “incredibly dangerous,” certified personal trainer James Dixon told BuzzFeed News.

“It can make a person incredibly insecure about their body, which can lead them to lean on unhealthy workout routines and diet plans,” he said. 

There are a number of certifications that fitness professionals can obtain, like CPT (certified personal trainer), CNC (certified nutritional coach), NASM (a course from the National Academy of Sports Medicine), and so on. Depending on the program, it costs roughly $500 to $5,000 to gain access to classes that can last between 4 and 15 weeks. Sometimes, creators list their certifications in an alphabet soup of initials in their bios, which fitness influencer watchdog Dorsey said is a red flag.

“I think a lot of fitness certifications are predatory because they rely on people thinking they need them to work at a gym when they don’t in most states,” he said. “I coach professional bodybuilders. There’s no certification that says, I’m good to help people get jacked and tan.” He clarified that he’s not giving any kind of medical advice — you shouldn’t come to him for weight loss guidance or tips to get started on your fitness journey, and you won’t find any on his Instagram either. 

Jaedon Mitchell, a certified personal trainer and nutrition coach, said that the power most fitness creators have over their audience has inspired a rise of unqualified influencers, which is “the worst thing that’s ever happened to the fitness industry.”

He said that one day at the gym, he saw a new member hanging upside down from a pull-up bar doing the “most absurd” exercise he’d ever seen, which could also result in serious physical injury. The gymgoer told Mitchell that he had seen on social media that the exercise could help with core strength. When Mitchell found the post online, he found that dozens of young people were excitedly commenting that they wanted to try it, too. The creator who shared the pull-up exercise had no official training at all.

“It was as if the influencer was the leader of a cult, creating these bizarre exercises on his own, and his followers believed everything without question,” he said. “Not all influencers without credentials are giving bad advice, but would you trust someone to do surgery on you if you weren’t sure they were a licensed doctor?”

Though it seems social media algorithms currently favor aesthetics over everything, some extremely successful fitness influencers shift the focus away from what they look like in a way that ex-influencer Axelson said she craved. 

Marshall said his goal is not to help people look good — it’s to help them feel good. Posting like other fitness influencers just doesn’t bring him the same level of joy as being goofy.

“I fell in love with making normal people feel like superstars,” he said. “We all have our moments where we’re not so confident, but when I tried to post like other people, it just wasn’t fun for me.” 

Marshall added that people were prioritizing their personal goals and emotional well-being during the early stages of the pandemic, which led to a craving for more authentic content like his. To him, the transformation of the fitness industry isn’t just possible. It’s already underway.

“Aesthetics will always be something that people chase, but we just found out how bleak the world can be,” Marshall said. “I think the influencers who are focusing on mental and overall wellness are the ones who will succeed.” ●

article:
"That '70s Show" Actor Danny Masterson to Face Second Trial After Jury Deadlock

In a case that has captured public attention, actor Danny Masterson from the hit TV show "That '70s Show" will be retried on three counts of rape. This decision comes after jurors in his first trial failed to reach a unanimous verdict. The trial, set to begin on March 29, will give Masterson another chance to clear his name or face the consequences.

Masterson, known for his role as Steven Hyde, stands accused of sexually assaulting three women at his Hollywood Hills home in 2001 and 2003. The recent mistrial declared by a judge in November left the charges unresolved, leaving room for a fresh legal battle.

During the initial trial, the jury leaned towards an acquittal on all three counts. However, Los Angeles County Deputy District Attorney Reinhold Mueller argued that the jury had overlooked crucial supporting testimony. Mueller expressed the importance of giving the victims another opportunity for justice, stating, "Not giving these victims another chance with a jury who can sit there and consider all of the evidence — win, lose, or draw — that would be an injustice."

The trial proceedings were marked by graphic testimonies from the three women accusing Masterson, as well as a fourth woman who also alleged sexual assault. Additionally, the Church of Scientology, of which Masterson is a prominent member, played a significant role in the trial. Former Scientologists among the accusers testified about attempts by church officials to shield Masterson from accountability.

In response to the mistrial, Masterson's attorneys filed court papers seeking a dismissal of the charges. They argued that the prosecutors' case suffered from significant evidentiary and credibility issues. However, Judge Charlaine Olmedo denied the request, allowing the prosecution to move forward.

If convicted, Masterson could face a maximum sentence of 45 years to life in prison. Throughout the proceedings, he has maintained his innocence, claiming that all sexual encounters were consensual.

Representatives from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner, which is representing the women in their civil case against Masterson and the Church of Scientology, expressed satisfaction that Masterson would not escape criminal accountability. They stated, "We are pleased that Danny Masterson will not be permitted to simply escape criminal accountability."

As the retrial approaches, attention will once again focus on the courtroom, where the fate of Danny Masterson hangs in the balance. The upcoming trial promises to be a crucial chapter in this high-profile case, with potential implications for both the entertainment industry and the fight against sexual assault.
